result.heading: M E E T J O E B L A C K

direction.raw_text: . ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. - 4:00 AM A patch of water. PULL BACK TO REVEAL more water.  BACK FARTHER TO REVEAL an expanse of river, up the bank to massive lawn running up to a great, classic Hudson River manor house; the country estate of William Parrish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: :00 AM MOVE THROUGH French doors that lead from a wide terrace into an expansive living room, DOWN wide corridors lined with Bierstadt and Cole paintings, the Hudson River School, mists and trees and small boats and distant humans.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: :00 AM MOVE THROUGH the doorway to reveal a master bedroom furnish- ed with exquisite simplicity, revelatory of its sleeping occupant, WILLIAM PARRISH, 64, a warm but commanding face, a man of maturity yet who exudes a glow of enthusiasm. Although asleep, there is an uncommon restlessness to him. Parrish grips his upper arm as if in pain.  Now the severity of the pain wakes him, he squeezes his arm.  The wind comes up, through the wind a VOICE is heard distantly, or is it the wind itself:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Yes. Parrish blinks, has he heard something, has he not, he is not sure, he releases his arm, his grimace of pain fades, the discomfort seems momentarily to have subsided. He rises now, crosses to the bathroom.  As he pees, a breeze outside the window, the wind again, but then the Voice comes up:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes... It is unmistakably a Voice, it is not the wind, Parrish has heard something, he looks around, but no one is there.  He can't finish peeing, turns back to his bedroom.  All beweild- ered, Parrish looks around once more, climbs back into bed, trying to trace the source of what he has heard or hasn't heard; he is not sure. He pulls the covers up now, not a SOUND, tries to close his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Parrish sits up again, frightened, but still there is no one there, he seems fraught with indecision, should he get up, should he not, what is happening?  He looks out: absolute stillness and silence, CRICKETS chirp down by the river, a light FLICKERS from a shadboat, Parrish closes his eyes but then they flutter open, he glances up at the ceiling and finally, exhausted, falls back asleep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The great lawn infested with workmen, planting stakes, un- rolling a huge canvas tent, gardeners fashioning topiary and adding landscaping of their own, crews setting up platforms, speakers, lights.  Ubiquitous is ALLISON, 35, Parrish's older daughter, foremen competing for her attention and she relishing every moment. A Painter approaches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The big tent, Miss Allison -- ALLISON Paint is rust and moss green. Medieval colors -- Daddy's like an old knight. A Florist stops her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The head table --?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The flowers, ma'am--?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Freesia, freesia, everywhere.  Daddy loves freesia -- and you, over there, lights.  Not too bright.  I'm looking for a saffron glow -- sort of tea- dance twenties.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Parrish, groomed for the day, trots down the stairs, observ- ing the activity outside through the windows.  He checks his watch, strides down the hall, encounters MAY, 50, a family retainer who is opening the doors to the terrace as Parrish passes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you think of all this, May?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's going to be beautiful.  And Miss Allison says the President may come.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, the President's got better things to do than come to my birthday party.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? Parrish grins, continues on, is intercepted by Allison who, on catching sight of him, bounces in from the terrace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Daddy!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, Allison -- ALLISON Have you got a minute?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not much more.  Big day in the big city.  What's on your mind?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fireworks.  Update -- we're con- structing the number '65' on the barge, archers from the State College at New Paltz will shoot flaming arrows at it, when it catches fire it will give us the effect of a Viking funeral with none of the morbidity... The Hudson River Authority says, for you, they'll make a special dispensation - of course there'll be an overtime bill for the Poughkeepsie Fire Dept...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Allison, I trust you.  This is your thing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But it's your birthday. Parrish smiles complaisantly, they continue on into a break- fast room where SUSAN, 30, Parrish's younger daughter, is grazing at a table laden with cereals and fruits and coffee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good morning, Dad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, honey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm Allison, you're 'honey'.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Drew called from the AStar, they're still two minutes away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Drew's aboard?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He wanted to ride back down with you. Now sit and relax, get some- thing in that flat tummy of yours -- But Parrish only pours coffee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You coming?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've got patients waiting, I've got three hysterical chefs, one loves truffles, the other hates truffles, the third one doesn't know what truffles are.  I'd better drive down. Parrish gazes at the going-on outside which are increasing in intensity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hate parties -- ALLISON Calm down, Daddy, you'll see, you're going to love it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Isn't it enough to be on this earth sixty-five years without having to be reminded of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Allison goes, Susan observes Parrish fidgeting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will you relax?  I know it is a big deal day -- PARRISH How did you know?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Drew told me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Does Drew tell you everything?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hope so.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You like him, don't you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.  I guess so. A moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't like to interfere.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Then don't. The helicopter CHOPS in overhead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here comes our boy now -- Shall we?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and May carry the overnight bags for the family as led by Parrish, they hurry towards the helicopter.  En route they pass QUINCE, 38, Allison's husband, who is perched at a portable bar with AMBROSE, the head caterer, tasting wines.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...This shit's not bad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The late harvest Riesling, Mr. Quince, a possibility for dessert.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pinot Grigio.  We're considering it for the appetizer. Ambrose takes a sip, swishes the wine in his mouth, spits it in a bucket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you do that for?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well sir, it's 9:30 in the morning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: :30's almost 10:30.  Where I come from, the sun's over the yardarm, m'boy, and the cocktail lamp is lit. Quince drains his wine, presents it for a refill, when he is hailed by Allison.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Quince!  Everybody's waiting! Quince downs this glass too, runs for the helicopter as
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a young man going places, emerges from it, approaches Parrish and Susan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, Beautiful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi. Drew kisses her, over her shoulder he glances at Parrish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good morning, Drew.  Thanks for coming out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, it's a big day.  Wanted to line up a few ducks before kickoff. Any thoughts?  Last minute refine- ments or variations?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Thoughts'?  Not a one -- but I did hear a voice last night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A voice?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In my sleep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What'd it say?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Yes'.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Yes' to the deal?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe, who knows?  You know how voices are.  Let's go. Quince comes running up now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, Bill -- PARRISH Good morning, Quince.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How're you doing--?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm doing great.  You ready?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am, this is it.  B Day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How's that, Quince?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bontecou Day.  Going to close with Big John -- Look at you, Bill, all cool as a cat and over at Bontecou's, I'll bet he's shitting in his pants.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Honey, please.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay.  All aboard - New York, New York!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Remember everybody, tonight, dinner in the city at Daddy's.  You too, Drew.  We've still got some loose ends -- PARRISH Not my birthday again?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're only six-five once.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank God.  Now could we go?  Let's get this day started. Drew ushers everybody on, first Parrish, then Susan and Quince, Drew the last to climb on, shuts the door behind him As Allison hurries away from the whirling rotors.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The configuration of seats has Drew beside Parrish, in front of them Quince and Susan opposite each other in single seats. Just as Drew removes color-coded folders from his attache case and spreads them out for Parrish on his tray table, the pilot waves to Drew, indicating 'phone call'.  Drew gets up and heads for the cockpit, Parrish scans the folders, glances over at Susan who is making some notes on a file of her own. He motions to her to please come sit beside him, she checks that Drew is still busy in the cockpit, tucks her papers into her carryall, and crosses over to Parrish who folds away the work that Drew set before him into his tray table, locks it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought you were in a meeting--?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am.  With you. He peers up ahead at Drew, on the telephone and gesticulat- ing intensely, right at home in the cockpit despite the CHOP of the blades and the pilot pressed up against him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you love Drew?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...There's a start for a meeting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know it's none of my business -- Susan doesn't answer for a moment, then impulsively kisses her father on the cheek.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, it's none of your business. Another moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you love Drew?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mean like you loved Mom?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Forget about me and Mom -- are you going to marry him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Probably. A moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't get carried away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uh oh -- PARRISH Susan, you're a hell of a woman. You've got a great career, you're beautiful -- SUSAN And I'm your daughter and no man will ever be good enough for me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I wasn't going to say that -- SUSAN What were you going to say?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Listen, I'm crazy about the guy -- He's smart, he's aggressive, he could carry Parrish Communications into the 21st century and me along with it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So what's wrong with that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's for me.  I'm talking about you.  It's not so much what you say about Drew, it's what you don't say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not listening -- PARRISH Oh yes, I am.  Not an ounce of excitement, not a whisper of a thrill, this relationship has all the passion of a pair of titmice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't get dirty, Dad -- PARRISH Well, it worries me.  I want you to get swept away.  I want you to levitate.  I want you to sing with rapture and dance like a dervish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's all?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Be deliriously happy.  Or at least leave yourself open to be.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Be deliriously happy'.  I'm going to do my upmost -- He smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know it's a cornball thing but love is passion, obsession, someone you can't live without.  If you don't start with that, what are you going to end up with?  I say fall head over heels.  Find someone you can love like crazy and who'll love you the same way back.  And how do you find him?  Forget your head and listen to your heart.  I'm not hearing any heart. (a moment) Run the risk, if you get hurt, you'll come back.  Because, the truth is there is no sense living your life without this.  To make the journey and not fall deeply in love -- well, you haven't lived a life at all. You have to try.  Because if you haven't tried, you haven't lived.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bravo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aw, you're tough.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry.  But give it to me again. The short version.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stay open.  Who knows?  Lightning could strike. Silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Forgive the lecture -- SUSAN I won't.  And when I tell Drew about it, he won't either.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You won't tell him, and even if you did, he'd clock it and punch it into his laptop in order to pull out some key phrases when he gives the Commencement Speech at Wharton.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're terrible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know.  But I'm the only father you've got. She kisses him on the cheek.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank God.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He doesn't care.  But thanks anyway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The AStar lands, an attendant, waiting with a luggage cart, rushes to open the door and unload the bags.  The passengers, Parrish paired with Quince, Drew with Susan, file off the rooftop through a door which opens into an elevator.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Parrish, Susan, Drew and Quince face forward as they ride downwards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, this is it, the hour approach- es, I'm getting all excited.  So what do you think, is it -- (indicates Drew and Parrish)

direction.raw_text: just the 'Executive Committee' or could you guys use me?

direction.raw_text: Quince, m'man, thanks for the offer, but it's all set for just me and Bill. More people might -- QUINCE I know.  Gum up the works. Parrish is about to make some reassuring comment to Quince when the Voice suddenly intrudes:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...I know, it's none of my business.'

direction.raw_text: I was saying to Quince we won't need -- PARRISH Did you just hear something?

direction.raw_text: Daddy, what's the matter?

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...I want you to levitate.  I want you to sing with rapture and dance like a dervish.' Parrish grunts bizarrely, Susan notices and reacts:

direction.raw_text: Just talking to myself again.  You know me -- The elevator door opens.

direction.raw_text: Well, here we are -- Parrish leads the group out.

direction.raw_text: Are you okay?

direction.raw_text: A-Okay.  Got my gloves on, my ears pricked.  I'm ready for action.

direction.raw_text: Well, go get 'em, Pops.

direction.raw_text: Yer damn right. Parrish, followed by Drew, steps into a waiting limousine, Quince looks longingly after them.  Susan, blowing a kiss goodbye to her father, steps out into the street to hustle a cab.

direction.raw_text: ...Tomorrow we sign off -- photo opportunity, you and Big John, it'll lead network news.  Okay so far?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sounds good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's going to be great -- PARRISH Do you think I need a haircut?

direction.raw_text: Bill, after this deal, you'll be able to afford one. Parrish smiles, they step into the elevator.

direction.raw_text: Parrish and Drew emerge from the elevator, Parrish observing the overkill decor.

direction.raw_text: Their PR guy asked me, what did I think Parrish Communications stood for, that's principle and ethics- wise?  I came up with something, but then it occurred to me, why don't I ask Bill?  What do you think? A moment, Parrish shrugs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Our first annual report, must be thirty-five years ago now, I owned two stations, I wrote down a state- ment of purpose, that one day you would wake up to a Parrish radio station, read a Parrish paper at breakfast, catch our news on tele- vision during the day, and go to bed with one of our books or magazines and you would always be told the truth and in the bargain, have a good time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's great!  Wait 'til I show it to Bontecou. Drew opens a door, a conference room, a circle of top exec- utives, now stepping out from the group is a huge, white- haired man, JOHN BONTECOU, 55.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bill, thanks for coming over... (to Drew) And how're you doing today, Drew? (to Parrish) You've got a firecracker here, the kid's really set the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good, good.  Glad to hear it.

direction.raw_text: We've met before, y'know, that White House function, the President had you on his right and you know where I was?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry, I don't recall -- BONTECOU Left field somewhere.  Well, Bill, I want to come in from the outfield, bat cleanup like you have, learn the plush ropes -- PARRISH I thought you were buying my company.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Mr. Parrish, I could never buy Parrish Communications.  I could pay for it, of course, but it would always have your imprint. Silence.  Parrish looks around at the circle of 'suits', Bontecou holding away.

direction.raw_text: Well, that's very nice to hear. Drew nods excitedly.

direction.raw_text: The busy medical community at 68th Street and New York Avenue.

location: NEW YORK HOSPITAL CORNELL MEDICAL CENTER
result.heading: EXT.

direction.raw_text: A thriving eatery diagonally across from the hospital's entrance, customers cheek-by-jowl as a pair of waiters juggle breakfasts served to a noisy throng of doctors, residents and interns. Susan has squeezed into a seat in the corner.  A counterman, with a smile and a greeting, places a cup of coffee in front of her.  A sense this is a daily ritual, arming herself for the day; immediately she becomes aware of a man behind her speaking into the pay phone. An attractive YOUNG MAN, early 30's, a pair of suitcase at his feet, a raincoat slung over his shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Honey, you've got to go on... there's a time to sow and a time to reap, you sow now and forget about him... yeah, I liked him, I don't like him anymore... because you're my honey and anybody messes with you messes with me -- I'm on a plane in a minute... as soon as I get my phone in, you're my first call, that's a promise... where you going now?... good, hit the books, get that degree, one day we'll hang out a shingle together... you bet, honey... later. The Young Man hangs up, turns around and sits down to an overflowing plate of eggs and meat, potatoes and toast, the counterman refills his cup and the Young Man ties into the breakfast, eating it with such relish that Susan can't take her eyes off him.  He senses her eyes, glances over, his cheeks filled with a mouthful of food, swallows embarrassedly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good morning, I was talking kind of loud there, sorry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not at all.  It was fascinating.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh yeah?  What was 'fascinating' about it?

direction.raw_text: You and 'Honey'?

direction.raw_text: My kid sister.  She just broke up with her boyfriend and she's thinking about dropping out of law school.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry -- YOUNG MAN Nothing to be sorry about.  That's the way with men and women, isn't it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the way?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing lasts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I agree -- YOUNG MAN Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was just being agreeable, now I've got to explain why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not trying to sharpshoot you, but that 'nothing lasts' stuff, that's what was the trouble with Honey's guy.  He was fooling around and Honey caught him at it.  One girlfriend wasn't enough for him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So you're a one-girl guy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Damn right.  Looking for her right now.  Who knows?  You might be her. Susan laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, don't laugh.  I just arrived in town, got a new job -- I'm trying to get into this apartment.  You a doctor?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How'd you know?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everybody's a doctor around here. This apartment house is all green pajamas and slippers.  The guy I'm waiting for to vacate is a doctor. What kind of doctor?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Me?  Internal medicine. The Young Man smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So if I needed a doctor, you could be it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I could be her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Her'. A moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I could. (a moment) I have an office in the hospital.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is my lucky day.  I arrive in this big bad city and I not only find a doctor, a beautiful woman as well. Susan looks into her coffee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry, you mind my saying that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not at all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How 'bout another cup of coffee?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've got patients coming in -- YOUNG MAN And I want to get into my apartment and go to work.  Please, what do you say, another cup of coffee? Two pots are warming behind the counter, he reaches over and refills her cup and his.  Pushes a container and pitcher to- wards her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see you use lots of sugar and cream.  Me, too... They smile at each other, fix up their coffee.
