location: CORINTH COFFEE SHOP, NEW YORK AVENUE
result.heading: INT.

direction.raw_text: A magnificent granite building, a monument to good taste in the midtown sea of glass and aluminum.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Parrish and Drew enter, no particular fanfare but an aware- ness the 'Chief' has arrived, everyone giving Parrish the appropriate wide berth, Drew right beside him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm all excited -- PARRISH Me, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought it was great, I thought you and Big John would be like a couple of bulls in a china shop -- (faltering) Instead it was -- PARRISH Like a marriage made in heaven?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have a way with words. They stride to the main bank of elevators.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Parrish, Drew beside him, proceeds through a high tech, but tasteful, maze, spiffy executive secretaries at burnished desks.  Neither looking right or left, somehow Parrish man- ages to acknowledge their bright smiles and deferential nods despite his swift entrance. He passes through an open set of doors and he is into his own suite, commanded by JENNIFER, his assistant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good morning, Mr. Parrish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, Jennifer. Drew is still at Parrish's heels, but now Parrish stops at the open door, turns back to him, reminding Drew that this is as far as he goes without being invited.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So... Board convenes tomorrow, you'll recommend, we close and it's a deal, right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As close as a deal could be.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Olympic. Parrish disappears into his office.  Drew, on his way out, glides past Jennifer's desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is our lucky day. Jennifer acknowledges Drew with a smile, rises and moves to Parrish's doorway, waiting for the day's instructions, but Parrish only nods to the door and Jennifer quickly closes it, returns to her desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alone in his office, Parrish's ebullient mood immediately changes.  Leaning against the back of the couch, he stares out through floor-to-ceiling windows, surveying the Manhattan skyline: cogitates. He takes a seat on the couch, opens a folder, suddenly he flinches with a spasm of pain in his shoulder.  It is sharp but brief, he notices it but what it does not continue, he ignores it. Parrish resumes looking at the folder when suddenly the pain comes again.  He reaches for his shoulder, tries to massage the pain, it does not subside.  Parrish stands, trying to shake it off, but it refuses to go away, some- thing is unmistakably wrong.  Now a SOUND which he has come to recognize, makes itself heard:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Frozen with surprise, Parrish's eyes search the room for the source of the SOUND, it comes from no particular direction, yet surrounds him.  Suddenly Parrish's symptoms sharply intensify, he is sinking to the floor but somehow grabs a corner of the desk, holds on with one hand, with the other clutches at his shoulder and arm, the pain has violently seized the upper part of his body.  He breaks out in a sweat, his pallor now waxen as the Voice repeats itself:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Yes. Parrish grips the edge of the desk, the pain assaulting him on the one hand, the Voice coming at him from the outer, each aberration feeds on the other, he is beside himself, consumed with pain and bewildered by what seems to be a hallucination but which he is certain is not.  Parrish is possessed.  He angles his face in every direction, arbi- trarily chooses one and now embarrassedly, unconsciously, enrage, responds to the Voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Yes' what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Yes' is the answer to your question.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't ask any question.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I believe you did. Parrish is absolutely confounded, seized up with pain and consternation at this unseen Voice which has such presence and reality.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who are you? Silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goddammit, what is going on?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think you know -- PARRISH I don't!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Try.  Because 'if you haven't tried, you haven't lived'. A moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you talking about?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What you were talking about. Parrish gasps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is this?  Who is this fucking guy? He holds on tight to the corner of the desk, sweat dripping, his skin ashen.  Now he addresses the Voice again, searching for it in another direction:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me who you are!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you giving me orders?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry, I -- VOICE No, you're not.  You're trying to 'handle' the situation but this is the one situation you knew you never could handle. A spasm, the worst one yet, finally it subsides and there is an eerie silence in the room, a VOID, almost more disturbing than the voice that has filled it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where are you?  Are you there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's enough now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please.  Talk to me -- VOICE There's going to be plenty of time for that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think you know -- PARRISH Know what? (a moment) Know what, goddammit! The VOICE is gone.  Parrish searches the corner, but the room has lost the quality it had when it was inhabited by the VOICE, it is now just Parrish's office.  Faint SQUEALS of traffic from the street, then a KNOCK at the door. Parrish touches his shoulder, the pain is gone, but he is still wet with sweat, the KNOCK again.  Parrish straightens himself up, adjusts his tie, runs his fingers through his hair, blinks as he addresses the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come in. Jennifer enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've been buzzing you, Mr. Parrish. Are you all right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lunch is 'in' today, have you given it any thought --_ PARRISH (interrupting) No.  Nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing? Parrish is within himself, doesn't answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why don't I think of something? Parrish still doesn't answer, however Jennifer is satisfied, correctly hearing his silence as an affirmative.  She has her hand on the door, 'Open' or 'Closed'?  He nods and she closes it. Utter silence again.  Parrish's eyes search the room, nothing there.
direction.name: direction

result.ToD: CORINTH COFFEE SHOP, YORK AVENUE, DAY
result.heading: CORINTH COFFEE SHOP, YORK AVENUE, DAY

direction.raw_text: . CORINTH COFFEE SHOP, YORK AVENUE, DAY The place has cleared out now, the counterman busy bussing tables laden with dishes and cups, Susan and the Young Man are still at the counter, but about to leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...It's kind of a pro bono job.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Pro bono'.  That means doing good
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Going to be doing good all your life?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know what you're saying.  Doesn't pay very well.  Depends on the woman I marry.  Maybe she'd like a bigger house, a better car, lotsa kids, college doesn't come cheap -- SUSAN You'd give up what you want for the woman you marry?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I would. Susan rises now, the Young Man with her, leaving money for their checks they head for the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If I married you, I'd want to give you what you wanted, I know it's old fashioned and all that, but what's wrong with taking care of a woman?  She takes care of you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll have a hard time finding a woman like that these days -- YOUNG MAN You never know.  Lightning could strike. Susan at the door now, pauses abruptly, her eyes on the Young Man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Young Man holds the door for Susan as they step out onto the street. Susan is staring at him now, he smiles, all open and vulnerable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've got to go -- YOUNG MAN Did I say something wrong?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, it was so right it scares me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've been thinking... I don't want you to be my doctor.  Because I don't want you to examine me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because I like you so much. (a moment) You have coffee here every morning, don't you?  If I came by, could you give me the name of a doctor? Another moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure, I'll give you the name of a doctor. (a moment) ...And I don't want to examine you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why not?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because I like you so much.  Now I've got to go. She hurries away down the sidewalk, the Young Man watching her.  Now he turns and starts off in the opposite direction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks back at the Young Man, then turns and walks on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks back at Susan as the distance between them widens, now he turns and walks on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks around once more but the Young Man is still headed in the opposite direction, his back to her.  She turns the corner and continues on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Approaching the corner, he looks back for Susan yet again, but she is gone, still turned he steps off into the street and a hospital supplies truck, speeding down the curb lane,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a horrific impact, the THUD echoes as his body arcs through the air. Another sickening THUD as it lands, the Young Man lies crumpled, still.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beautiful space adjacent to the dining room, it has a glass roof which offers a superb view of the Manhattan sky- line.  The hour is before dinner: gathered on one side of the room are Allison and Parrish, on the other side Drew and Quince.  COYLE, a butler, and LUISA, the housekeeper, pass hors d'oeuvres and drinks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Music, I know how you love music, Daddy, and I want to have music that pleases you -- and of course doesn't put a thousand other people to sleep
direction.name: direction

location: SALON, PARRISH TOWNHOUSE, NEW YORK CITY
result.heading: INT.

direction.raw_text: I've agonized over this and finally settled on Sidney Brown, twenty-four men, very eclectic, plus I'm feathering in a Latin sextet on their breaks - Tito Puente, Trini Lopez-zy, I forget their names -- Parrish has tuned Allison out, he tried to stay with it, but his mind has wandered, the event of the day too much with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You haven't heard a word, have you? I keep talking and all you do is nod like Mr. Himmelfass in The Nutcracker. Parrish still doesn't answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't care, do you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What, honey?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I lay awake nights in a cold sweat, I want this party to be like some- thing Mom would have made for you, I want it to be perfect -- PARRISH (attentive now) I know you do, darling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you could care less -- PARRISH Oh, you couldn't be more wrong, sweetheart.  I can' tell you how much I appreciate it and how I'm looking forward to it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good.  Songs.  What songs should Sidney -- Pancho and his six men we can forget about -- what songs do you think he should play? A stab of pain, Parrish discreetly grabs his upper arm but manages to keep his attention on Allison.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell it to me again. Suddenly, the Voice cuts in:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Yes. Parrish's head snaps, startled by the SOUND.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you miss me? Parrish reacts once more, aware again he is the only one who has heard the Voice, as an oblivious Allison continues:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Never mind.  Leave it to me. Parrish ignores her, his attention has been taken by the Voice.  His eyelids flutter, nonplused, edgy and fearful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Parrish, dinner is served.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chow-time, you guys. Parrish is confounded.  Blindly and disconcerted, he follows Allison and Drew and Quince.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to Quince and Drew, across the room)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As a disturbed Parrish approaches the table, he hears the Voice once more:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you looking so provoked about?  'Did you miss me?'  It's a normal question.  I missed you. But what do I get back?  'Not an ounce of excitement, not a whisper of a thrill --' Parrish sits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This relationship has all the passion of a pair of titmice'. Parrish is on the edge of his seat, struggling to hide his panic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm waiting outside. The conversation swirls on around Parrish, he is deaf to it:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you speak to the Governor?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's coming.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His wife?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Unfortunately.  I sat between them at the Bronx Zoo benefit -- it was better than Seconal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm waiting outside.  Won't someone come to the door? Parrish is in shock, still striving to gain control of himself.  As Coyle serves him, Parrish turns to Luisa:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is somebody waiting outside, Luisa?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't hear a ring, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please have a look -- Luisa goes as Coyle continues serving.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about the Mayor?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He said he would be there with bells on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good, maybe they'll drown him out. Parrish is still not hearing a word, preoccupied with the return of Luisa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please don't be negative, Drew, we have an acceptance list that would do The White House proud -- The Secretary-General of the UN, the Chairman of the FCC, nine Senators, I don't know how many Congressmen, and at least twelve of the Fortune
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No jocks?  A twenty-game winner or a Masters champion?  Someone I could talk to. (a moment) Or would talk to me. Luisa returns to Parrish as the others' conversation drones on:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're right, Mr. Parrish.  There was a gentleman at the door.  He's waiting for you in the foyer. Parrish is stunned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Show him into the library, tell him I'll be right there. Parrish, spinning with anxiety, tries to summon up his courage to go as Allison continues:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've arranged for favors -- silver charm bracelets for the women, platinum keychains for the men -- all engraved 'W.P.' -- but now I'm thinking of scrubbing them, they seem so ordinary. Finally Parrish rises from the table, starts out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are they ordinary?  Do they seem that way to you, Daddy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uh -- I don't know.  No - uh - I don't... Allison is about to press the point, but then drifts into disappointed silence as Parrish leaves the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're overthinking it -- QUINCE I don't think they're ordinary.  I love keychains.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Parrish moves deliberately down the hall, slows as he nears the doorway to the library.  The door is open.  He hesitates before he crosses the threshold, taking in as much as his eye can see, now tentatively, he enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beautiful, classic room, areas of dim, warm light, club chairs, books reaching to the ceiling, a rolling library ladder, a weathered dictionary on a stand, a model boat carved of bone set into the stacks which are separated from the reading area by a seven-foot high partition of obscured glass. Parrish, poised in the doorway, looks around, nothing in sight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello? Silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anyone here? No response.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I said is anyone here?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Quiet down. Parrish is startled, he shrinks backward for a moment, his eyes searching the room for the Voice, the timbre and pitch of which is exactly what he has heard before.  There is the sense that someone is there but Parrish cannot see him, and he does not dare look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm here. Now a flicker of a shadow from behind a corner of the obscured glass, the section of the room most distant from Parrish, there is a shape.  Something is there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is this, a joke, right?  Some kind of elaborate practical joke? At my 40th reunion, we delivered a casket to the Class president's hotel room and -- VOICE Quiet. Parrish falls silent, something in the SOUND and TONE of the Voice muting him.  He takes a step backwards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where are you going?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - I - uh -- The shape moves, makes itself more visible.  Although still diffused by the glass, the shape has definition, a person, a man, his features are not yet distinguishable, but he is there all right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The great Bill Parrish at a loss for words?  The man from whose lips fall 'rapture' and 'passion' and 'obses- sion'...all those admonitions about being 'deliberately happy', what there is no sense 'living your life without...', all the sparks and energy you give off, the rosy advice you dispense in round, pear-shaped tones -- PARRISH What the hell is this?  Who are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just think of millenniums multiplied by aeons compounded by infinity, I've been around that long, but it's only recently that your affairs here have piqued my interest.  Call it boredom, the natural curiosity of me, the most lasting and significant element in existence has come to see you. Parrish struggles to make sense of what he is hearing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: About what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want to have a look around before I take you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Take me'...?  Where?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It requires competence, wisdom, experience -- all those things they say about you in testimonials -- and you're the one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'The one' to do what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Show me around.  Be my guide.  And in return, you get...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the hell are you talking about?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Watch it!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry -- VOICE In return you'll receive minuets, days, weeks, I'm not going to go into details ... what matters is that I stay interested. Parrish squints, trying to make sense of what is happening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Yes' is the answer to your ques- tion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What question?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bill.  Come on.  The question.  The question you've been asking yourself with increased regularity, at odd moments, panting through the extra game of handball, when you ran for the plane in Delhi, when you sat up in bed last night and hit the floor in the office this morning.  The question that is in the back of your throat, choking the blood to your brain, ringing in the ears over and over as you put it to yourself -- PARRISH The 'question' -- VOICE (urging) Yes, Bill.  The question. After a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Am I going to die? The figure who is the Voice takes a step forward now, no longer obscured by the glass he comes into the light, re- vealing himself to be the Young Man seen previously in the coffee shop, but there is a change; he seems odd, off- center, not handsome but terrifyingly beautiful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. A moment, Parrish beside himself.  He cannot bring himself to speak, finally:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Am I dreaming this? (Another moment) Are you a dream?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am not a dream.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're coming to 'take me'.  What is that?  Who the hell are you? The Young Man steps closer to Parrish, his face is inches from a shaking, sweating Parrish's face, the Young Man daring Parrish to identify him:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are --?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Yes --' Parrish turns away.  But the Young Man, spectacularly, is in front of him again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who am I?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Death. Parrish is shocked, stunned, terrified at the word, by what he has comprehended.  He surveys the Young Man who, at this moment, actually seems bewildered by his effect.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're Death?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Death!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not Death.  You're just a kid in a jacket and a pair of pants.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The jacket and the pair of pants came with the body I took.  Let me ask your opinion.  Do I blend in? A hopelessly confused Parrish does not respond for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want me to be your guide --?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You fill the bill, Bill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do? (a moment) How long will you be staying?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You should hope quite a while.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And then --? The Young Man nods, gently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's... it's... over. A long silence.  Parrish and the Young Man take each other in, the sense that now they understand each other.  A SOUND at the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Parrish? Parrish does not hear her for the moment, Luisa steps inside the Library.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will the gentleman be staying for dinner, sir? Parrish ignores her at first, finally he looks at Luisa then at the Young Man, then once more at both of them as if to verify the Young Man's presence has been acknowledged by Luisa.  The Young Man interjects:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. (a polite afterthought) Thank you. Luisa nods perfunctorily and exits.  Parrish is frozen, dumbfounded.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where is dinner? Parrish does not answer at first.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is crazy -- you're not going to eat dinner with us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bill, I am eating dinner with you. And your family.  And that's what we're doing.  It's not open for discussion.  Nothing is.  Don't you understand? Parrish is frightened by the response.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good.  Now lead the way. Parrish hesitates, then obediently leads the Young Man out of the library, down a long hallway and across the foyer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me?  Could I say something?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It just occurred to me -- YOUNG MAN Speak up, please.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When I introduce you, if I say who you are, I don't think anyone will stay for dinner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then don't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Parrish and the Young Man enter, Allison is heard in the background.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Well, here's another possibility. It's a little last minute, but how does this strike you?  Kaleidoscopes. Little gold kaleidoscopes.  Some German firm went kerplunkt, Tiffany's picked these things up, they're perfect party favors, however they're not personal, they're winter scene or something, snow-flakes and dachshunds... Parrish and the Young Man appear at the table, an awkward pause ensues, the unannounced guest's presence at a family dinner being noted, and the guest himself carefully survey- ed.  Finally, Allison breaks the ice:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi there -- YOUNG MAN Hello. Parrish is horribly uncomfortable as the Young Man looks at each person as if he were discovering a face of the first time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uh -- sorry -- to have stepped away for so long -- uh -- this is a friend of mine I asked to drop by -- we got to talking and stuff -- uh -- he's going to join us for dinner -- um -- Parrish drifts into another awkward pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, how nice to meet you.  And wouldn't it be nicer if my father would introduce you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...How nice to meet you.'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I'm sorry.  This is my daughter, Allison, and her husband, Quince, Drew, my number one, works with me... Parrish drifts off as the Young Man awkwardly shakes hands with each person.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Daddy.  Does your friend have a name?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A name?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, something he goes by -- PARRISH Oh, excuse me.  This is -- uh -- this is -- ALLISON Daddy!  Come on, a name.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, Bill, the suspense is killing me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry...um - you - you know it's gone right out of my head -- DREW What?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry.  This is - uh - uh... The group waits patiently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe... Parrish once more drifts into silence.  (The YOUNG MAN is now identified as "JOE".)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just plain 'Joe'?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Love that name.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Me, too.  Hey, buddy! Joe, turned on by Quince's broad smile, reacts to it as Drew squints observingly at Joe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is there any more to it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Like 'Smith' or 'Jones --' Parrish's face reveals a desperate searching for a last name, a furtive glance at Joe.  Parrish's brow darkens and a name tumbles from his lips:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Black.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whew, at last.  Nice to meet you, Mr. Black.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Joe Black'.  Won fifteen and lost two for the Brooklyn Dodgers in
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You bet.  I'm kind of my Rotisserie League.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is!  Let's sit down -- Luisa has set a plate in front of Joe, and Parrish's, which was taken to the kitchen to be warmed, has been returned. Joe looks over at the other guests, then picks up his uten- sils gingerly, strives to copy the others, stops, staring at his foot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paillarde of veal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, they hit the calf over the head with a mallet and then Luisa hits it again in the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Honey --!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know what I'm saying, Joe?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No -- PARRISH (laughing emptily) Joe knows what you're saying, just being polite -- Drew is studying Joe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have we met?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uh -- he's from out of town -- QUINCE How long you here, Joe?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As long as it takes. Drew is provoked by the response, but remains polite:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You and Bill old friends? Parrish jumps in:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No -- DREW (to Joe) I get the feeling you've done some business before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have an arrangement now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What side of the industry did you say you were on?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe sounds like a ringer, Bill.  I have the feeling you guys got the broad strokes already.  Need any help with the details? Parrish falls silent again, looking for an answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry -- business at dinner... (to Joe) Forgive me for being so rude.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure. The doors to the dining room open, Susan appears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, everybody.  Sorry to be late - had to have dinner with my depart- ment chief -- ALLISON You ate?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...I'm here, aren't I?  Wouldn't miss a loose end meeting.  What's on the table for discussion?  Party favors, flowers -- hi Dad, hi Drew -- She kisses Drew in some light, humorous way they have ob- viously done before, their heads bobbing like plastic water toys and their lips meeting mid-air. At the kiss's conclusion Susan suddenly notices Joe is present and has been watching.  She is shocked, embarrassed, pleased, conflicted, an instant and wide spectrum of emotions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you doing here? Silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know each other?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We've met.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This morning.  The Corinth Coffee Shop.  He was looking for a doctor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I guess he's found one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe, you do get around. Joe is happily confounded by all the interaction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's your name?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And isn't it a lovely one?  So sturdy, so straight -- Joe has heard Susan's question but, as he studies her, doesn't answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Incidentally, Joe, where're you staying?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Here'?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In this house?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Great! Parrish pushes his plate away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uh - will that hold you, Joe?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Incidentally, 'Joe' what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Black.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, this is fun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So, what are you doing here? Parrish tenses, but Joe doesn't answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cat got your tongue?  You weren't so silent this morning. Drew reacts to this allusion of intimacy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, I'm getting interested.  I want to know more --- PARRISH (to Joe) We've got some things to discuss. Parrish stands, motions for Joe to rise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did I hear 'business'?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What 'business'?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't bother asking, we already tried.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's so very nice to see you again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Funny, I don't get that feeling. Maybe it's because you found out I'm Bill Parrish's daughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cut it out, Susan. (to Joe) You and I've got to talk.  Big day tomorrow, everybody.  Joe, let's go. Joe rises, follows Parrish to the door, stops:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Susan. (to Allison) Allison. (to Quince) Quince. (to Drew) Drew. (to Parrish) Bill... (to the group) Thank you. He makes an awkward little bow, then heads for the nearest door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe, that's the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. Joe pivots, and he follows Parrish out the proper door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That was 'Joe'.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's cute.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very. Susan's eyes are still on the door where Joe exited, her face reflecting her irritation and bewilderment, as well as a tinge of excitement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Parrish leads the way, Joe beside him as they progress through the huge house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...I'm sorry, I'm a little discon- certed, that stuff between you and Susan -- uh -- threw me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Threw' you?  Where?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shook me up.  I mean that you knew her and everything -- JOE I didn't know her.  The body I took knew her.  The man she met in the coffee shop this morning.  I - uh - took him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So there's nothing between you and Susan?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wish you had said something to me about staying here -- JOE It hadn't occurred to me until then. I was just having such a wonderful time -- Besides, isn't this what I'm here for? Parrish suddenly looks very anxious, Joe stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You seem uncomfortable, Bill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I'm okay with this - uh - I think.  So -- He opens a door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Joe) Bathroom...tub...towels, sauna -- Parrish turns back to the bedroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Chair, lamp, bed -- Parrish is in a stunned state, chatters on unconsciously:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Box springs, they're assembled in Jakarta.  Had to stay in a station manager's house there unexpectedly - best night's sleep I ever had. Ordered twenty, they filled a con- tainer and shipped them right over, I've put one in every bedroom here and in the country. Joe tests the springs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What a good idea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you.  Would you like the man's name?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Parrish glances around, a room in which the occupant could not want for anything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If there is anything else, don't hesitate -- JOE I won't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How long have I got?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're putting me on the spot, Bill. A moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's put it this way.  When I go, you go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When you go, I go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's the best I can do. (a moment) ...but minute-by-minute, I find myself lingering.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...I just saw my doctor, he told me everything was fine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your doctor? (icily) Did your doctor say anything about a tiny, undetectable hole in your aorta?  Did he mention an irreparab- ly weak vein in the further reaches of your famous brain?  Were they any prognostications about the possibil- ilites of a fatal collision on a golf cart of suffocating in an avalanche on a skin vacation in Gstaad?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No -- JOE I hope you realize, Bill...in your office this morning, that was your time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Closer than that. Parrish keeps still, trying to cool the heat of Joe's temper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...But meanwhile, you are still here.  Count your blessings.  Call it gravy, frosting on the cake, whatever it is you say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, thank you for letting me know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not at all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And - uh - I  guess, 'goodnight'.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good night to you, Bill. Parrish gently closes the door. Joe looks around, checks out his surroundings: curious, attentive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Parrish, unsteady, starts back down the hall, Luisa appears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Miss Allison asked if you would like to have your dinner kept warm?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Thanks, Luisa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very good, sir. Luisa turns:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Luisa -- She stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Black's luggage was misplaced by the airlines.  Would you mind get- ting a few things together for him? A couple of suits, some shirts, ties, underwear, shoes.  Have Coyle take his measurements off what he is wearing tonight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Certainly, sir. Luisa nods, and heads back downstairs.  Parrish enters his den, takes a seat in his chair, stares into the middle distance, ruminates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe has been examining his room, full of curiosity and wonderment at the oddest things, the handle on a casement window, the hem and weight of the fabric of a drape, hinges on the bedroom door.  In the process he opens this door, steps out into the hallway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe wanders down the hallway past the occasional Dufy or Miro, a Venetian tapestry cheek-by-jowl with a miniature Ming vae, and even a Bonsai garden with a trickling vein of water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the "back" of the house now, utilitarian paint and decor, the SOUND of laughter and a glare of light.  Joe enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The staff is at ease, some smoking, remains of food around. Coyle, the butler, has his back to Joe and does not see him for a moment.  In front of Coyle, an open jar of peanut but- ter which he is spreading in generous hunks of Wonder Bread. Joe is fascinated by the process.  Coyle suddenly hears the silence, looks up and see Joe, standing up embarrassedly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello.  I'm Joe Black.  Nice to meet you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes sir, Mr. Black, a pleasure. The staff all mumble expansive "Good evening, sir"s to Joe. He motions to them to sit, they do but Coyle does not.  Coyle shifts from foot-to-foot, the staff is not used to having Parrish family or guests in this part of the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you eating.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mean this, sir? Coyle regards his peanut butter sheepishly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Laura Scudder's Peanut Butter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Laura Scudder's Peanut Butter'. (a moment) You like it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I would say, sir, it is right up there with Jif and Skippy.  But miles ahead of Peter Pan. (another moment) Like a taste? Joe nods, Coyle fashions a spoonful, offers it to Joe.  Joe swallows it.  But he has not yet found a comfortable way of masticating, his mouth and tongue go every which way, the staff observes him, fascinated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a peanut butter man now, eh, sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I am.  I thoroughly enjoyed this - uh - peanut butter. (to the staff) And I thoroughly enjoyed meeting you. Joe raises the spoonful of peanut butter in a kind of toast to the staff.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll be moseying on. He heads out, with the spoonful of peanut butter, to cheer- ful "Goodnight, Mr. Black"'s, his tongue again licking the edges of the spoon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A spectacular indoor Olympic pool, window commanding views of the skyline. Susan is swimming laps, looking very professional in a black Speedo suit, Joe wanders in, still licking his peanut butter. He observes her, but she is unaware of him, however now, as she makes a barrel turn, his shadow falls over a reflection from a window, she aborts her lap, looks up to see who it is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you doing here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm lost.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can't seem to escape you today.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry. Susan climbs out of the pool, gets halfway up the ladder, points to a stack of towels.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hand me one of those, will you? Joe turns to the towels, but one hand is occupied with the spoonful of peanut butter, he shifts it to the other hand, can't manage the huge Turkish towel one-handed, now implants the spoon in his mouth, lifts the towel with both hands and presents it to Susan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You must have something really big going on with my father -- JOE 'Big'?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You appear at his side out-of-the- blue, stay at his house, eat dinner with his family, it's practically a first.  You're in the red-hot center of big business and I thought you were a regular Joe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am Joe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not the one I met this morning, hit- ting on me in as nice a way as I've been hit on in a long time, but the moment you find out I'm my Dad's daughter, you act like a stranger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That is not my intention. Joe continues to nibble at his peanut butter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are your intentions?  To make little dreams in coffee shops, turn a woman's head, and I don't mind admitting it was turned, I liked it, but ten hours later I feel like a fool.  I don't get it.  You, my father, here in this house, the cof- fee shop, it's making me upset, and I don't like being upset.  Who are you anyway?  And what are you eating?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peanut butter. He finishes the spoonful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But it's gone now. He shifts the spoon from hand to hand, starts to stick it in his pocket, realizes this is inappropriate.  Susan holds her hand out to him, he places the spoon in it and she sets the spoon on the table with the towels.  She watches, fascinat- ed, as Joe licks his gums, enjoying every last bit of his spoonful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You act like you never had peanut butter before -- JOE I haven't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What kind of childhood did you have?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you love Drew?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come again?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When you put your mouth to his, Susan, it seems a frequent thing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Drew is none of your damn business. Nor is where I put my mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry.  Do you live here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, Joe, I'm swimming here.  Then I'm going home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess what I'm trying to say is -- I'd like us to be friends.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've got plenty of friends.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't have any.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can see why. She finishes drying herself, drops the towel on a chair, and prepares to leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...I didn't mean to offend you at dinner.  I'm not quite at home some- times with people.  I get busy doing - uh - what I do, and I don't seem to have developed -- He drifts off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes --?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have a certain function to per- form, and that seems to take all of my time.  Bu sometimes - uh - I speculate - uh - I haven't left room for - uh - anything else.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry to say I know what you're saying. A moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Susan?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you know you have a wet spot on your shoulder? She glances at her shoulder, he grabs a towel, touches the drops of water, pats them dry, hands her the towel.  She flashes a nervous smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goodnight, Joe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goodnight to you, Susan. Susan steps towards a door, Joe takes a step in the wrong direction, they almost walk into each other.  Now she takes a step in another direction, as does Joe, again they almost collide.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shall we dance? Joe is completely puzzled, finally Susan heads for one door, Joe for another.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe -- JOE Yes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think you want to go to the west wing.  Through there. Susan indicates yet another door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. Joe redirects himself, goes to the door.  As they both are about to exit, Joe and Susan sneak furtive looks at each other across the pool, smile at catching each other's glances.  Joe exits.  For a moment Susan's eyes remain on the door through which he has gone.  Now she grips the towel over her shoulders, the one Joe gave her, pats the same spot he did.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Parrish, dressed for the day, passes servants busy with their morning tasks, polishing doorknobs, putting away linen, dusting picture frames.  He nods and greets them as he strides down the hall, brisk "Good morning"'s to Coyle and Luisa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Parrish knocks, waits a courteous moment, opens the door, finds Joe in an elegant shirt and trousers trying to tie his tie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good morning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good morning, Bill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How are you?  How're you feeling?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Feeling'?  I feel fine.  How do you feel?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Um -- well, I didn't sleep too well. This is crazy.  This is the left- field thing of all time.  What do I do?  What do I tell my family?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I wouldn't tell them anything, Bill.  You'll ruin the good start we had last night.  I felt as if I were being treated like a person.  'Joe' this and 'Joe' that - a nice smile - Quince passed me the rolls -- no 'rapture' or 'passion' or any of those mighty things you seem so intent on imparting, but I am cer- tain, should you - uh - say - uh - who I am - our adventure would end abruptly. Parrish regards Joe, the tie is a sorry mess now, a batwing of silk stretching across his collarbone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But I did so enjoy your family. Parrish is startled, he regards Joe carefully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about my family?  This 'adven- ture' involved only me, right? Silence as Joe considers the point, Parrish quickly crosses to him, undoes the tie, and now begins tying it for him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell you what, you promised that it's going to be only me and -- JOE And what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I won't tell anyone who you are.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sounds fair enough.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is a deal?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'deal'?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You give your word, I give mine -- that we'll do what we say.  It's a truth exchanged between two people. A moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bill -- PARRISH Yes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've got a deal. Parrish seems relieved.  He has now, with some difficulty, completed the tying of Joe's tie, adjusts it beautifully on Joe's collar, then spins him around in front of a mirror. Joe, catching sight of his own appearance, rises to the balls of his feet, quite taken.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is great! (a moment) Now what do we do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shake hands. Joe immediately extends his hand toward Parrish, but Parrish freezes on seeing the hand, stares at it, now takes it.  Joe pumps Parrish's hand vigorously, then breaks into a broad smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Parrish and Joe striding downtown, Joe's jacket fits per- fectly, he blends right in and he clearly enjoys being part of the smart Fifth Avenue crowd on the way to work.  Parrish senses Joe's pleasure, his slight preening, his eyes check- ing out the good-looking women headed for the offices at the top of corporate high-rises.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know, I got to thinking last night -- with you here, and seem- ingly occupied, how's your work going - uh - elsewhere? A flicker from Joe.  He has heard what Parrish has said, his eyes busy with the grift and the sparkle of the Avenue, but he is concentrating on Parrish's words.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When you were shaving this morning, you weren't just shaving, right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You were hatching ideas, making plans, arriving at decisions, right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess so.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So you understand the concept then. When you're busy here, your work, what your task is, is being executed elsewhere.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So you've grasped the idea.  Con- gratulations.  Now multiply it by infinity and take it to the depth of forever, and you still will have barely a glimpse of what I am talking about. Parrish falls silent, chewing over Joe's admonition.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe --?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Bill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How about giving a guy a break?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Make an exception?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's one to every rule.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not this. They stride on, cutting through the crowd, Joe all at home in his new surrounding, but Parrish just the opposite, un- characteristically uncomfortable, phrases forming on his lips but unspoken, then suddenly he blurts out:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't deserve this.  I'm still young, this is not my time -- JOE That's what everybody says.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not everybody.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's what everybody says. Parrish is trying to control himself, glances at Joe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want to live.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I understand. A moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you can't. A sudden silence between them.  Parrish's shoulders appear to have stopped slightly, the courage he displayed at rais- ing these issues has vanished.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's it like?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's it like where I'm going?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can you keep a secret?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So can I. They turn into Parrish's office building.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Parrish and Joe enter, Parrish is hailed by JAIME, the Elevator Starter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good morning, Mr. Parrish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good morning, Jaime.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Knight's Reward in the 4th at Calder -- A bemused Parrish walks on, Joe beside him, Jaime pursuing them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A closer in today with cheap speed.  The colt will come from the clouds and boom!  Fifty-eight dollar horse.  I get you down, Mr. Parrish, just say the word.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry, not today, Jaime. Parrish and Joe arrive at the bank of elevators.  Jaime, back at his post, hits a button.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know, everyday I've walked into this building, Jaime gives me a horse. (a moment) I wonder if any of them won. The elevator materializes, Parrish and Joe step on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Parrish and Joe emerge from the executive elevator, Jennifer is waiting as usual with her pad, "Good morning"s, etc.  As Parrish strides down the hall, Joe right beside him, he passes instructions back to Jennifer who, scribbling, hurries along behind them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And call my family, I'd like them to come over for dinner tonight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Didn't the family get together last night --?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jennifer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course, Mr. Parrish.  Right away. Jennifer wheels and heads right back to the office as Parrish arrives at the door to the Board Room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Perhaps you would like to wait in my office --?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What I'm trying to say is this is a Board meeting and you are not a mem- ber of the Board.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sure you'll see to it that it won't be a problem. Parrish hesitates, nods, conceding the point, reaches for the doorknob.
direction.name: direction

location: PARRISH COMMUNICATIONS, OFFICE OF THE CHAIRMAN
result.heading: INT.

direction.raw_text: Parrish enters, Joe following right behind him.  A euphony of "Good morning"'s from the various members of the Board, including Quince.  Everyone sits when Parrish does but Joe, right at home, spots a tray of refreshments: coffee, pas- tries, he heads for them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is Joe Black, a personal associate of mine - uh - he'll be joining us today.  I know it's -- uh -- unusual, and my apologies -- and Drew -- uh -- carry on. Immediately indications of surprise on Board members' faces at Parrish bringing in an 'observer', Drew's reaction guarded but intense.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nice to see you.  I didn't expect you, but certainly you can't get enough of a good thing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Board of Parrish Communications - is hereby called to order.  Our sole order of business is an acceptance of John Bontecou's generous offer and -- JOE (to Drew) Do you have any more of these deli- cious cookies? A hushed silence at the inappropriateness of Joe's inter- ruption.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And a cup of tea.  With milk, I think.  I'd like to try it English- style.  Yes, a cup of tea with milk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anything else, Mr. Black?  How about some water?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why yes, thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hot or cold.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cold.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And a glass. Drew indicates to the Board's Stenographer to arrange Joe's refreshments.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would you like to sit down, Joe?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Joe sits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To review -- we're really crossing the 't's and dotting the 'i's here. Bill had a great and conclusive meeting with John Bontecou yester- day, all that remains for us is to put it to a vote. Smiles and murmurs of a congratulatory receptiveness from the Board at Drew's news.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Drew. Parrish takes a moment, draws himself up to say something official then stops himself, what follows is spontaneous, reflective, deeply felt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Umm -- I did enjoy -- or rather I was interested in meeting John yes- terday -- impressive... I suppose... But it did get me to thinking.  I started in this business because this is what I wanted to do.  I knew I wasn't going to write the Great American Novel, but I also knew there was more to life than buying something for a dollar and selling it for two.  I wanted to give the news to the world, and I wanted to give it unvarnished.  The more we all know about each other, the greater the chance we will survive. Sure, I want to make a profit, you can't exist without one but John Bontecou is all profit.  If we give him license to absorb Parrish Communications, and he has his eye on a few others after us, we'll be appointing him to the position he craves -- Gatekeeper.  In order to reach the world you will have to go through John Bontecou.  And not only will you have to pay him to do this, far more expensive, you'll have to agree with him.  Reporting the news is a privilege and a responsibility and it is not exploitable.  Parrish Communications has earned this priv- ilege, John Bontecou wants to buy it.  As your chairman, I urge you to agree this company is not for sale. A silence, everybody shifts, the Board is in shock, Drew is trying to maintain his balance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Sounds like you're not leaving much room for discussion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry.  I know it looks like I'm reversing my field.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's your privilege, Bill.  But given our needs, given the absolute necessity for growth, given the fu- ture, the truth is... joining John Bontecou is every bit as certain as - Death and Taxes. Joe interjects:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Death and Taxes'? After a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Death and Taxes"? Another moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What an odd pairing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's just a saying, Mr. Black,
direction.name: direction

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is this a state secret or are we being excluded just for the fun of it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Susan's patient is whom we are talking about.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe visited the hospital today. Parrish's head swivels to Joe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did he?  That's more than we get to do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, maybe next time Joe goes, he'll take us along.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Perhaps you could remind me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll make a note of it.  Anything else?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd like to come, too.  See Susan strut her stuff.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're on, Quin-cee.  Destination Hospital.  Joe, you'll be the Tour Guide.  Okay?  How's that sound to you? Silence.  Parrish regards Joe, then Susan, his face reflects a sudden concern with their relationship.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Susan is a wonderful doctor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: After dinner, the family and guests file back in from the dining room, Drew alongside Parrish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have to go, Bill -- it's been a helluva day.  Need a few minutes to sort everything out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, we'll see you tomorrow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure. Drew peels off, heads for the foyer and front door, Susan follows him. Parrish corners Joe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why did you go to the hospital?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You were just curious?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: About Susan?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wouldn't put it that way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What way would you put it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You tell me, Bill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How about you telling me?  When I ask a simple question, I expect a straight answer.  That's what I'm used to.  Anybody who doesn't give it to me, I fire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you going to fire me, Bill? Silence, Parrish is at a loss.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Drew is putting on his coat, Susan with him, a tension between them, a heavy silence finally broken.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...See you tomorrow night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Include me out.  I've had enough of the conversations.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't mean that.  You wouldn't disappoint Daddy -- DREW Daddy'll do fine.  Besides, he's got Joe. (a moment) And so do you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Drew, you're out of line.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That may be.  But I don't like the fucker.  I don't like the way he looks at you and talks to you.  And vice versa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry, but I like the way he looks and talks to me.  And vice versa. Okay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, not okay.  I thought we had a good thing going here. (a moment) It shows you never know. Silence, neither knows how to continue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well... goodnight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.  Goodnight. Drew goes, Susan turns to find out at the far end of the foyer, he's been observing them.  She walks up to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How long have you been standing there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't like the way Drew spoken to you.  But I feel better about it now because of the way you spoke back. A moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me about yourself, Joe.  Who you are.  What you're doing with my father. Susan's directness has caught him by surprise, Joe blinks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So you're not going to tell me? Joe remains silent, rendered extremely anxious by Susan's inquiries.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're married, aren't you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because guys who never say anything about themselves are always married. Joe doesn't respond.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So you are married.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I'm not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Girlfriend?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Susan comes closer to Joe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then tell me, Joe, how come a man as attractive, intelligent, well- spoken ,diffident in the most sed- uctive way, and yet powerful, is all alone in this world? Joe tries to respond but he can't, his stammer interrupted by Susan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry, I don't want to pry and you don't want to tell me.  So let's leave it a mystery.  That's the way you want it, isn't it? Susan takes another step closer to Joe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, I appreciate that. They are inches apart now, the smell of each other surrounds them, a heaviness to the moment, now Joe turns to head up the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where are you going?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'To bed'?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.  I'm tired. He excuses himself with an ineffable gesture, now climbs the stairs, Susan watches him disappear. She turns back into the salon just as Allison and Quince are exiting, "good-byes" all around.  Susan is left alone now with Parrish who is fixing a drink at a sidebar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That was wonderful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, it's good to get together.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you mind if I raise a little caution flag?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Raise away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is the nature of your interest in Joe?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, remember how you told me about "lightning striking"?  The nature of it's in there somewhere. Parrish drops another cube of ice in his drink, takes his time before answering.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I won't say you may be getting onto shaken ground -- SUSAN Then what will you say?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think this is the lightning you are looking for.  Drew's a good man.  I know I didn't seem to be completely in his corner before, but I've come to appreciate -- SUSAN Now we love Drew and Joe in verbo- ten?  What's going on?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When you say 'nothing' that way, it's not nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then what is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's something. She kisses him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: G'night, Daddy.  See you tomorrow. This is getting interesting. She goes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A large suite, room service carts creaking with pots of coffee and half-eaten pastries.  The Board of Parrish Communications is gathered, absent are Parrish and Quince. Felicia, Drew's secretary, takes notes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...I know you're all as uncomfor- table as I am to be meeting without Bill, but I got a call last night from John Bontecou.  Not only is he still interested, he is sweetening his offer. (a moment) Although it pains me to say it, in my opinion Bill Parrish dealt with us peremptorily in dismissing any deal with Bontecou.  Therefore, I'm sorry to say that if we are to exam- ine this new offer responsibly as the Board of Directors of Parrish Communications, we must do so with- out its Chairman. (another moment) Oh yes, there is one additional element: Bontecou is so anxious to get us, he said he'd take Parrish Communications with our Chairman or without. The Board falls silent.  Sloane, a peer of Parrish's, fidgets.  Drew milks the moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's no surprise if I suggest to you that the Bill Parrish we know is not the Bill Parrish you saw yesterday. You heard that speech -- some strange emotional rationale to buttress a knee-jerk rejection of a legitimate offer.  Does it not strike you that something is possibly affecting this man's judgement?  More specifically
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: his judgement to make a critical business decision? Silence, the Board clocking Drew's argument.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not pleasant to say the follow- ing, but I would be remiss, in this crisis, if I did not.  When we pre- sent Bill with the improved Bontecou offer, and if he refuses to let us consider it -- once more makes an adamant or emotional rejection -- we will have no choice but to seek an alternative.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And what would that be?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bill's birthday is the day after tomorrow.  There is a provisory by- law in our charter.  Per the discre- tion of the Board, Corporate off- icers can be retired at age sixty- five.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're taking this too far, Drew.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Am I not obligated to? Drew leans over to Felicia, speaks quietly and she leaves the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How did this all come about?  Crisis
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bill Parrish, crisis -- his com- pany, crisis for us.  I came about with the arrival on the scene of -- Mr. Joe Black.  Mr. Joe who?  Joe Black.  He attends our Board meet- int, he sleeps at Bill's house, re- sides in his office.  Never leaves his side.  And, in my opinion, is always in his ear.  Telling him what to do and Bill is listening.  Who is Joe Black?  What is his relationship to Bill Parrish?  And most important, what is behind his influence on our Chairman?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're building this thing up too much, Drew.  He's had advisors be- fore.  Nobody tells Bill what to do. The door opens and Felicia enters followed by Quince, sur- prised at seeing a convened Board, but still he is all smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you for coming.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, Quince.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, Ed, hi folks, I didn't know everybody was going to be here, what a nice surprise.  What's the big confab?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is a secret meeting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hope you'll respect its nature -- What we're trying to do here is gather our thoughts -- in light of Bill's rejection of Bontecou's offer
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and make an appropriate presenta- tion to him as to how we think the company might proceed.  Won't you share with our Board the information you gave me last night? Quince hesitates, then realizes what Drew has on his mind. He nods confidently to Drew, then turns importantly to the Board.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I'm happy to tell you I've got good news.  As I was telling Drew, I've been making a little hay while the Bontecou sun was shining -- two, possibly three new and boiling hot prospects for merger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How did Bill react to the leads you've developed?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He was interested.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But he was concerned about the timing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The timing -- yes.  He says it's up to Joe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'It's up to Joe'?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's what he said. Quince, having dispensed his information, looks proudly around at the Board members.  They are stunned, Sloane in shock.  Drew is absolutely still, letting Quince's words sink in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Parrish, Joe, Susan, Allison and Quince are seated at the table, dessert plates in front of them, coffee cups beside. Allison and Susan's eyes are on Parrish, looking for some clue as to why has he gathered the family together yet again.  Parrish is somewhat within himself, but he peeks over his demi-tasse cup at Joe, Parrish aware of Joe's heightened interest in Susan, and Susan's reciprocation. Coyle enters carrying two imposing stemmed silver trays with cakes on them, Luisa follows with one other.  They set them down in front of Parrish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Annie made them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's Annie?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From La Rosette, only the greatest pastry chef in America. (pointing) This is orange, from real Seville oranges.  Lemon, on a mille-feuille crust, a little on the fanciful. And a while, nothing like a good old white cake, vanilla, with Angel food but some maroons shavings thrown in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't like cake.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's for the party, Dad -- PARRISH Oh, the goddam party -- ALLISON 'Goddam party'! Allison bursts into tears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you hear that? Quince quickly slashes a piece, takes a huge bite.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is great, honey.  The orange. Has it got a little vodka in it? Like that Finnish stuff, orange vodka -- (to Parrish) Put your lips around this one, Bill. It's out of this world.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No thank you, Quince. (to Allison) I'm sorry, honey.  I'm no good at this.  Why don't you choose whatever cake you like?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I knew you were going to say that. Tito Puente.  The old platoon.  Now the cake.  You just don't care.  Why did I do this?  I should have my head examined.  I'm trying to throw the party for the century for my father - and you know what -- he doesn't give a shit. She bursts into tears all over again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But he does give a shit.  Don't you, Bill?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, I give a shit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: See.  There.  What'd I tell you? Joe watches as Quince dabs at Allison's tears with a napkin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Feel better?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, but -- QUINCE But what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What will I tell Annie? Parrish forks a bit of a cake.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The vodka.  What'd I tell you? Quince puts a reassuring arm around Allison, she seems to relax now, Joe has been a keen observer of what has trans- pired between husband and wife, between man and woman, a sense that he has taken in the virtue of such a relation- ship.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: After dinner, Parrish, Allison and Susan are gathered to- gether.  At the bar on the other side of the room, Joe watches as Quince pours himself a stiff hooker of brandy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cirrhosis of the liver is the fifth leading killer of adult Western males.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't know that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On the other hand, Winston Churchill drank a bottle of cognac a day and lived until he was ninety-one. After a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're an original, Joe.  A little hard to figure, maybe...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you're a nice man, Quince.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're welcome.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Drew appears unannounced in the doorway, exchanges a tense glance with Susan, then heads straight for Parrish who seems surprised to see him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry to intrude, Bill, but we've got a bit of a crisis downtown -- it's not something we could talk about on the phone. Parrish takes Drew aside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Board's real unhappy, Pappy -- they felt you dealt with them pre- emptorily, you never gave them a chance to speak -- PARRISH What is there to say?  They know what John Bontecou is -- and if they didn't, they know now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, you made your feeling abun- dantly clear.  Now they want to do the same with theirs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are their feelings?
