direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If I read this Board right now, they want you to accept Bontecou's offer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Over my dead body. Parrish's burgeoning anger has now gotten the attention of Joe, Susan, Quince and Allison.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you think the Board is going to say when I tell them that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't care.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With all due respect, you damn well better care because if you try to stonewall them again, there'll be blood on the floor. Silence, Parrish carefully calibrating Drew's remark.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whose?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yours.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm feeling real uncomfortable right now because the guy who reports to me is threatening me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm just giving you the truth.  There was a time when William Parrish liked the truth. Joe, although across the room, is all attention.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think it's time you went home, Drew.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Certainly.  Goodnight. Drew goes, everybody is in shock, Susan pursues him out into the hallway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Drew! He stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Never talk to my father like that again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't worry about it.  There's a beginning and a middle and an end to everything.  And I think I've come to the end of my chapter with the Parrishes. Joe has followed them into the hallway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And the end began with this guy. Drew looks down towards Joe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Black --?  We ran a check on you and you know what we came up with?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I don't -- DREW Not good, not bad, you know what we got?  Nothing.  No credit, no cars, no mortgages -- no wives.  Nothing. Joe waits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All of a sudden a guy appears on the scene with the Chairman of one of the greatest communications corpora- tions of the world, the boss makes him privy to all the company's secrets, he attends the Board meet- ings, and us working stiffs with MBA's up the ass and years and years and years of experience, we're left outside with our noses pressed against the window. Joe doesn't respond.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is a big-time operation, deal- ing in big-time issues, demanding big-time executives who make big- time decisions.  So, Joe, why don't you tell me exactly what it is that's big time about you? After a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You first.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why don't you get off his case?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, you're the great Joe's attorney now?  Are we going to go to court? Or are we going to go to bed?  And I don't mean you and me.  I mean you and him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's it.  It's over.  Get out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So I guess a blowjob's out of the question? Joe clears his throat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you say something? Joe considers him evenly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Almost.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I said get out. Now Drew wheels, heads right for the front door and exits with a SLAM.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What an angry fellow. A moment passes before Susan realizes she and Joe are alone, and Joe does as well.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry about -- JOE Please.  We don't need to talk about Drew. She regards Joe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.  We don't. They drift, osmotically, into the library in awkward silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brave you had a chance to look at Dad's rare books?  Jefferson's Parliamentary Manual, a first edition Bleak House -- Joe comes closer, takes a deep breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love your smell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess you haven't. Now Susan, close to Joe, leans closer, her nose in Joe's neck.  Joe holds himself very still.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I like your smell, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was everything. Silence, the TICKING of the clock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When I was little, my mother used to say, "Darling, you could set your heart by this clock".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Could you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Never tried, 'til now. (suddenly) Joe, may I kiss you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why, yes.  Thank you. A moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're welcome. Susan reaches out for Joe, they kiss, he is awkward but his very awkwardness endearing.  Susan pulls him closer, they linger now, mouths on each other's, then separate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're welcome. The clock TICKS on.  A sense of foreboding falls over Joe's face, his fear that he is passing through some barrier, a point of no return.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe? The apprehensive expression on Joe's face fades away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know who you are.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well...I'm -- uh, Joe.  And you're Susan.  And I - uh - have this weak feeling in my knees -- SUSAN And is your heart beating strangely?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Faster.  And I want the scent from underneath your ears and the taste of your lips and the touch of your tongue to stay with me -- forever. An intake of breath.  She is about to speak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you don't even have to say a word. Their faces inches from each other's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have to go home. But neither Susan nor Joe moves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't I? Her question makes Joe, almost involuntarily, smile.  Susan takes the opportunity to step back from him.  The SOUND of someone at the door, it is Parrish, Susan turns, comprehends immediately how the situation will appear to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goodnight, Daddy. She drifts right past him, exits.  Joe and Parrish are left alone now, eyes on each other's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, Bill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello.  Would you like to join me, Quince and Allison for a nightcap?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Um -- not right now. An awkward moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay.  Goodnight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goodnight. Parrish turns and exits, Joe's head inclines, he breathes in the scent of his collar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Parrish, followed by Joe, emerges from his private elevator, is greeted as usual:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good morning, Mr. Parrish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good morning, Jennifer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Board is waiting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Didn't you call a Board meeting? Jennifer sees Parrish is trying to right his balance, she knows better than to press the point.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, the members are waiting.  They are in the Board room now. Jennifer nods respectfully as Parrish doesn't cast a flicker of any further surprise, heads straight for the Board room, Joe right beside him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Parrish and Joe enter, the entire Board is assembled, includ- ing Drew, Quince and Sloane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good morning. An odd mixture of responses, the Board sheepish and at the same time looking their most dutiful at this odd meeting, its sudden convening clearly a problem for Parrish, a prob- lem which he does not attempt to hide, only control.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you want to have a cup of coffee or something, Bill?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think so.  Do you? Drew gets the message, at the same time Joe is checking out all the attendees, his eyes come to rest on Drew.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To get to the point, we have re- ceived new information from John Bontecou concerning his desires for this company to merge with his, and we wanted to set the details before you. A moment as Parrish looks around, the moment extends, it appears he may not ever answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bontecou wants a quick response and -- PARRISH The answer is no, quick enough for you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't you want to hear the details?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not interested in the details. And I'm not interested in the big picture either.  What I am inter- ersted in is how my Board got conven- ed behind my back, is entertaining a further proposal from a man whom it offends me to do business with, moreover has the audacity to present this to me like a prize fish, and I am expected to clap for it like a performing seal.  No, thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So I am to understand from your re- sponse that you do not want to hear the details of Bontecou's offer?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, you are to understand that, and now may I ask you a question?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Certainly, Bill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you running this Board or am I? Sloane leans in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're not getting anywhere here. Why don't we take some of the best out of this thing, let's consider it coolly, let's take a week -- DREW Bontecou wants a speedier response than that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He'll wait -- PARRISH Doesn't need to.  Today, tomorrow, a week from now -- 'a week from now', who can think about a week from now -- the answer is going to be the same -- a loud, unmistakable, all-inclusive, airtight -- 'No'.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: amongst the Board, they finally rustle into silence under Parrish's withering glance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's it?  I've got a busy day and this meeting has already set me behind.  Shall we adjourn?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Before we do, while we're here, there is a second question the Board would like a response to, a far simpler one. Parrish waits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who is the man sitting to the right of you? Everybody's eyes are on Joe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've already introduced Mr. Black to you all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But who is he?  What are his creden- tials?  What is his relationship to you? No response from Parrish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The feeling of the Board is this: we fear Mr. Black is not only influenc- ing your decisions in regard to this company, but that you are relying on him to make them for you. Quince flinches at these words, his hands clasped in front of him, his knuckles white as Parrish regards Drew, but still does not answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The lack of response, Bill, is not appropriate.  We are your Board, we have a right to know how you are managing the operations of this company, and most importantly, that you have not delegated someone to do it for you. Parrish squirms, desperately uncomfortable but still does not speak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, one more time. Drew regards Joe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who is Joe Black? Parrish stares stoically into the middle distance as Quince's head sinks into his hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A motion has been brought before the Board to invoke Article 19 of the corporate charter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In English, please.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mandatory retirement upon our Chairman's sixty-fifth birthday. Parrish is expressionless.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At which time, the Chairman will be named Emeritus, he will be welcome to attend all meetings, and will serve as International Spokesman for the corporation plus, of course, a settlement, a golden parachute of such magnitude that his feet will never touch the ground. Drew pauses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please indicate your vote by a "Yes" or "No". A "Yes" is heard, now another "Yes", now more "Yes"es, all reluctant, "No" from Sloane, "No" from Quince who realizes he is the instrument of Parrish's dismissal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The motion is passed.  We will of course delay the announcement, out of respect for our former Chairman, until after the celebration of his birthday this weekend.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you for allowing me to save face, Drew. Joe's eyes are riveted on Drew.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The other motion before us is the acceptance of John Bontecou's offer to merge this corporation with Bontecou International -- Parrish stands, Drew stops speaking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe? Silence, then Joe rises.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who I am, and my relationship to Bill, will be divulged in our own good time. Joe follows Parrish out of the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sloane has pursued Parrish and Joe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...It's not over, 'til it's over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please, Eddie, no 'Fat Lady Sings" shit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I still sense some doubt in this group, we could turn it around. You'll be up in the country?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, the big 'celebration' of my mandatory retirement birthday. You're an honored guest, Eddie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm going to stick it out here.  We still have a shot. The elevator door opens, Parrish and Joe step inside and the door closes, leaving Sloane behind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Board meeting has broken up, clusters of members have lingered, exchanging post-mortems.  And enraged Quince has cornered Drew, out of earshot of the others.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What have you done?  You've gotten the old man fired!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That we did.  Thanks to you.  He was wobbling, mind you, but you stupid the coup de grace. Quince falls silent, aquiver with this reality.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm going to put a stop to this!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Quince, you can't unscramble scrambled eggs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But I didn't mean to do it!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The train's left the station, pal, and you're aboard.  Would you like to hear the silver lining?  Check that, gold.  I've been working with John Bontecou all along.  We had a game plan -- acquire Parrish Communications then break it apart and peddle it piece-by-piece to the highest bidder.  I set it up for him, he smacks it out of the park. Quince is struck dumb.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't you know what this'll mean? You'll be rich.  You'll sell your stock, you can stop kissing ass -- What'll it feel like to be a man?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't want to get rich this way -- I'm going to expose you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go right ahead.  Tell William Parrish how you betrayed him at a secret Board meeting.  And tell Allison how you got her father fired -- and he lost his company. Quince goes ashen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's just life, Quin-cee. Drew hails an employee across the hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wake up and smell the thorns. Drew joins the employee as Quince slumps against the wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Parrish enters, Joe right behind him, Coyle takes their coats, disappears.  Parrish hesitates for a moment, shrugs as if he has a thought he doesn't want to share, then heads upstairs with Joe.  He is trudging a bit, Joe senses his mood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry, Bill -- PARRISH That's okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's okay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just a manner of speaking. Joe seems puzzled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What 'okay' is, it's 'okay' it's over.  We've got bigger fish to fry, don't we, Joe?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Fish'?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Never mind.  I'm tired.  I'm going to take a nap. A moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you hungry?  Coyle will have Luisa fix you something to eat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not hungry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then I can't help you. Parrish turns into his bedroom, closing the door gently behind him.  Joe continues down the hall, enters the guest wing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Midday sunlight streams into the sitting room, Joe passes through to his bedroom, sits tentatively on the bed, feels the edge of the silk spread, touches the pillow, then rises again, crosses back to the sitting room. Susan appears in the doorway, Joe suddenly senses her, turns around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am. He stands, they regard each other for the moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: May I take your coat? She doesn't answer, starts to take off the coat herself, Joe comes around her to help, Susan senses him breathing in the scent at the back of her neck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just thought I'd drop by, scrounge a little lunch, I was in the neigh- borhood -- JOE How beautiful. He starts to hang Susan's coat up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just throw it on the chair. Joe holds her coat carefully on the chair.  An awkward moment, the two of them shifting from foot-to-foot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When I called, they said that you and Daddy had just left the office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's taking a nap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He must be tired -- this Bontecou thing -- JOE Yes, he's tired.  I believe so. A moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You must be hungry? Susan sits on the couch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, not anymore.  Are you? Joe hears the question but doesn't answer, sits down on the couch beside her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (after a moment) Are you cold?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe it's the draft through the door. She gets up, closes the door, sits back down again next to Joe.  A warm, awkward silence, they move closer to each other, now they fall into a foreplay which Susan recognizes as such, Joe, on the other hand, participates hungrily but has no knowledge where it is leading.  His movements are instinctive, the smell of her hair, the shape of her fin- gers, odd things about her seem to interest him.  This excites her because she senses his untutoredness and the very sense of that stirs her, their reactions to each other are intuitive and spontaneous; even though Joe has no know- ledge of how to make love to a woman, ironically his actions are such that they never beg the question -- has he done it before. Strange territory for Joe, not to be 'in control' and exert- ing his power, but his inventions and responses in lovemak- ing are so real that an emotional exchange between he and Susan builds.  Joe has found himself in an unexplored land of feeling and passion, he loves what is happening and yet at the same time, is terrified by it.  He feels himself being lured by some power he has not only never been aware of, but is deeply dangerous to partake of; he knows what he is doing is putting who he is at great risk, yet he goes right on. The powerful contradiction is transmitted to Susan, and in the end there is the knowledge they have together made a journey, they both have been swept away in a stream of events they have created; and they don't care about the consequences. Spent, they lie in silence.  Finally Susan speaks:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's so wonderful to make love to you.  It's like making love to some- one who has never made love before. Joe senses an opportunity not only to admit to what she has said, but to tell her more, even the truth about himself. He weighs, then resists, the impulse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. Her head nestles underneath his arm, she has a sense of his comforting her without knowing that he is doing so.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you like making love to me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I loved it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: More than you love peanut butter?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes! She laughs at the earnestness with which he answers. Joe seems to drift away now, they lie together as one but for the first time, she feels separate from him, sensing him gone to some distant, distant land.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where are you going?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nowhere?  I'm...here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For how long?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I hope a long, long time. A moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Me, too. Another moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do we do now? She smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It will come to us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe and Susan are at the front door, he has helped her on with her coat, she turns around, they kiss.  The kiss lingers, Susan breaks away, reaches for the door, looks back longingly at Joe and then she is gone, Joe closing the door softly after her. He turns back into the foyer, looks up, Parrish is on the balcony, it is clear he has observed Joe and Susan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, Bill. Parrish, in a state of shock, doesn't answer for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you have a nice nap?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I couldn't sleep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry to hear that. He starts up the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I'll come down Joe waits guardedly at the bottom of the stairs as Parrish descends.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's going on? Joe senses Parrish's tone, doesn't answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I saw you kiss Susan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I saw you see me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, you're at the wrong place at the wrong time with the wrong woman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll be the judge of that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm her father!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With all due respect, Bill, I'm not asking your permission.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, you goddam well should.  You walk into my life, give me the worst news a guy can get, have me dancing on the heads of pins with my busi- ness and with my family, and now you're spooning with my daughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Spooning'?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, and stop repeating everything I sai, and turning it into a question. Spooning, fooling around, God knows what.  You arrive on the scene -- why you picked me, I still don't under- stand -- JOE I picked you for your verve, your excellence, and for your ability to - how shall I say - instruct.  You've lived a first-rate life.  And I find it eminently usable. Parrish measures Joe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you want? Joe doesn't answer, riveted now on Parrish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everybody wants something, Joe. You've been taking me from pillar to post here.  I thought I knew who you were, and it wasn't a whole lot of fun, however it was almost bear- able.  Now I'm getting something else from you, something very, very strange -- what is it that you want, Joe?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm only following the Parrish bywords.  Looking for that 'ounce of excitement', that 'whisper of a thrill' -- What there is no sense living your life without.  You know what I mean, Bill. Parrish's jaw sets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're violating the laws of the universe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This universe?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Any universe that exists or ever existed.  You may be the pro, Joe. But I know who you are.  And you're all fucked up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't like your tone, and I don't like your references.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I don't give a shit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: May I remind you this is not just a dispute with a putative suitor, this is me.  So watch it...Bill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cut the 'Bill' crap out -- you sonofabitch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I told you, 'watch it'. Silence.  Now Joe turns on his heel, heads right out the front door.  Parrish is left solitary, confounded, staring at the closed door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe walks down a hallway, a bouquet of flowers in hand, looks around the usual feverish activity, he seems lost for the moment, but a Receptionist catches his eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can I help you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dr. Parrish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She comes on at 6.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh. He looks at the flowers, regards them for a moment, then heads for an elevator.
direction.name: direction

location: EMERGENCY ROOM AREA, NEW YORK HOSPITAL
result.heading: INT.

direction.raw_text: Easter is sitting up in bed, hooked up to an TV and moni- tors.  She glances over at the doorway, Joe is standing there, observing her.  An awkward silence, he looks at his flowers again, now sets them respectfully on Easter's bedstand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mistah Bad News.  'Bout time you show up. Joe speaks to her in the dialect.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don' be facety, woman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: None facety, mistah.  You come for me?  Dat's good news.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I come to see Doctor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doctor?  What could be wrong wit' you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nuthin'. Silence, then Easter smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, you come to see Doctor Lady?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My Doctor Lady?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mine, too. She thinks about this for the moment, Joe grows uncomfort- able.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You in love? Joe seems slightly tormented by the question, Easter senses him trying to frame a respect.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You loved back?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She knows you real self?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She knows how she feel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rass!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don' need you okayin'.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schoolboy tings is you head. Badness for you, badness for her, badness for me, lyin' here tumor, big as breadfruit, poison my inners an' waiting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brung you flowers and all I gettin's facety back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only flowers I wan' see's one's over my peaceful self restin' in the dutty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can do no right by people.  Come to take, you wan' to stay, leave you stay, you wan' to go.  Rahtid! Silence, Easter waits, watching Joe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You not in you right place, mistah. Easter's response stops Joe cold, he looks away and then back at her, she had clearly reached him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I ain' either.  No more.  You come wi' me now.  Take me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But I not lonely here.  Somebody want me here. Easter considers Joe, she smiles sympathetically.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It nice it happen to you.  It like you came to Cat Island and you had a holiday, sun didn't burn you red, just brown, sleep no mosquito eat you, rum no poung you head nex' day. But trut' is, dat bound to happen, you stay long enough.  So tak dat nice picture home wi' you, but don' be fooled.  We lonely here mostly, too.  If we lucky, we got some nice pictures. Easter drifts into silence, her eyes and Joe's meet, a sense they understand each other.  Easter shifts, trying hard to ease her discomfort.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Got enough nice pictured, Easter. She looks at him and nods gratefully and closes her eyes. Joe watches her, now his eyes close.  Easter exhales raspingly, falls still.  The monitors flatline.  A beeping alarm sound somewhere down the hall. Joe opens his eyes, takes a deep breath, he seems troubled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: G'bye, sistah. She slips out of the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Parrish is playing solitaire.  The SOUND of the front door closing, HEELS crossing the foyer, he looks up, at the foyer door is Susan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, honey. He starts to get up, she motions to him to stay, looks around now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where's Joe?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe? A silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe's not around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where is he?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know. Susan seems distracted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why are you looking for Joe?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because I was sitting in a staff meeting, incredibly bored, my mind kept wandering and the only place it landed was -- Joe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't understand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Love.  Passion.  Obsession, all those things you told me to wait for.  Well, they've arrived. Parrish blinks, stares down at his cards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is crazy -- SUSAN Why?  A man appears at your side, almost never leaves it, you clearly trust him, depend on him, I sense you value him deeply, why aren't those things good enough for me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't know anything about Joe -- SUSAN What are you afraid of, Dad?  That I'll fall head over heels for Joe -- well, I have -- as you did with Mom. (a moment) That's always been standard, whether you like or not. Parrish tries to get hold of himself, changes gear now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Susan, I don't think Joe is going to be with us long.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where's he going?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know, I can't say -- SUSAN C'mon!  The guy's working with you. You always know chapter and verse about everyone who works -- PARRISH In this case, I can't.  I - uh -- I just can't help you.  I only would tell you -- that with Joe, you are on very, very dangerous ground. Susan doesn't answer for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't care if you love him!  I'm telling you he's no good for you! A moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course not, Daddy.  I'm sorry. There is something in Susan's tone that lets him know not a word has sunk in.  Parrish slumps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love you, too. She kisses Parrish, rearranges one of his ranks of cards, shuffles through the deck, turns over the top card, lays down a card Parrish needs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lightning does strike. Parrish watches as Susan turns, disappears out the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe walking disconcertedly up the street, bumping shoulders with the rush hour crowd, trapped in the life of the city, he peers intently at faces, cars, into store windows.  He stops now at the window of a Korean grocery, something has caught his eye, he steps inside. Through the window, Joe can be seen making a purchase, he hands the Korean Clerk some money, walks out. Joe, back on the street now, unscrews the top of a jar of peanut butter, dips a wad out with his fingers.  The Korean Clerk runs out after him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Change!  Change! Joe stops, uncomprehending.  The Clerk hands Joe bills and coins.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why are you giving me money?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Change.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am who I am.  I cannot change. Joe tries to hand the money back, but the baffled Clerk refuses it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You change!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's impossible.  You're wasting your money.  I couldn't change even if I wanted to. The Clerk, exasperated, murmurs something in his language and returns to the store.  Joe continues on down the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Parrish is sitting in a wing chair staring at the fire.  Joe appears in the doorway, Parrish doesn't notice him.  Joe waits, finally Parrish looks up.  They regard each other. Silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uh -- PARRISH Yes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have the feeling that, all in all, what I made this voyage for -- has served its purpose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you saying, that it's time to go? Joe doesn't respond, Parrish and Joe measure each other for the moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm ready.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good.  Tomorrow, after the party. Parrish nods, Joe nods back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HELICOPTER POV, HUDSON VALLEY - AFTERNOON A bird's eye view of the Hudson, over the George Washington Bridge, past the widest expanse of the river at the Tappan Zee, coming in now over the great lawns and old estates of the Upper Hudson Valley, down towards Annadale-on-Hudson and the Parrish country estate, which commands a beehive of activity, tents and workmen and vehicles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Parrish AStar sets down in its roped-off landing area. The Butler runs towards it to open the door, Parrish and Joe disembark.  Following the Butler, they make their way through the maelstrom: tents being raised, platforms for music groups, portable pools with clusters of florists leaning over the edge to arrange lily pads within.  Parrish and Joe move solemnly, observing the activity, not speaking to one another.  Although they are shoulder-to-shoulder, there is a distance between them.  They walk on past chan- deliers in the garden and fake trees with lights woven through their branches.  Adding to the confusion, the AStar lifts off, the chandeliers rocking and floral pools rippling from the blast of the rotors.  May, the housekeeper, appears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Telephone call, sir.  Mr. Sloane from New York. Parrish nods, starts up for a wing off the main house, Joe right at his side.  Parrish stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me. Joe, not knowing whether to be affronted or not, hesitates, and Parrish strides away.  Joe does not follow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A low-slung but well-appointed room with a writing table, a working fireplace, expensive and appropriate Hudson Valley prints. Parrish enters, clicks on the SPEAKERPHONE, observes the party activity through a wide, bow window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eddie?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah - Bill - How are you?  You okay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fine, fine.  Big doing up here.  Why are you still down here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Board's working through the weekend, trying up the loose ends this damn thing.  But I want to give it one more try, I'm still holding out some hope.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eddie, hold out all the hope you want but, I promise you, it's hope- less, it's over.  Come on up, let's get drunk, if I had your shoulder to lean on I might actually enjoy this -- SLOANE (O.S.) (speakerphone) No, I'm going to stay down here, keep my finger in the dike and maybe by Monday, the waters could recede.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you're trying to show me lay- down-in-front-of-the-bus loyalty, forget it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry, Bill, have a drink, eat your cake, blow out the candles and make a wish.  Talk to you Monday.  Okay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, Eddie -- anyway, thanks for the memory. Parrish clicks off the SPEAKERPHONE, turns around and looks out the window again, the party preparations in full swing, colored lights are tested, they flicker on and off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Allison is everywhere, Parrish emerges from his wing, she catches his eye immediately, the calm director of a DeMille- like epic, politely giving workers instructions, making lightning decisions. Parrish turns his attention now to an ice-filled fountain encircling two giant topiary letters written in faux- Cyrillic, a 'B' and a 'P', as rubber-booted delivery men carefully arrange giant ice chests of caviar under each letter.  A smile creases Parrish's face as, in an unexpected lull, Allison backs into him at the fountain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, Daddy, what do you think?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's starting to grow on me.  But what do the 'B' and 'P' mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The fountain is the Caspian Sea and the Sea is serving up caviar.  The 'B's for Beluga, the 'P' for Petrossian.  Of course, they also stand for 'Bill' and for 'Parrish'.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do they, m'dear?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Plus we've got a baritone with a balalaika coming from The Russian Tea Room.  I've dressed him in a Cossack shirt and he'll sing Nelson Eddy songs. Parrish shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are amazing.  Why, oh why, Allison, are you doing all this? But before she can answer, a workman is tugging at Allison's sleeve, she turns away from Parrish to give him instructions out of Parrish's earshot, and then turns back, they step away now, daughter and father, alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do it because I love you.  Because everybody I loved you.  Mommy -- wher- ever she is -- Susan, Quince, the people who work for you, everybody who's ever known you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah?  And what about my enemies?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They respect you.  Isn't that a kind of love? Unexpectedly, Allison brushes a lock away from Parrish's forehead, with a flick she has rearranged his hair, he blinks, a little embarrassed, but having liked it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Above all, you've been a wonderful father.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I haven't been the father to you that -- ALLISON That you've been to Susan?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wasn't going to say -- ALLISON But that's what you were thinking. And that's okay.  Because I know you love me.  Not like it is with Susan, the way your eyes light up when she comes in the room and the way she always gets a laugh out of you, as opposed to me when I walk in a room and that look comes over your face, "What does she want now?" A weather-beaten military parade ground pennant passes, 24th Infantry Regiment  "C" (Charlie) Company.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I already feel I've had everything I could have wanted for my birthday -- PARRISH Hey, there's lots to come. (gesturing to me activity) A little excess -- like you love. The preparations are building to a climax, all the elaborate plans coming to fruition.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know, darling, this is going to be a wonderful party.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, it is. Allison wades into the maelstrom now, Parrish watches her go, swarms of purveyors and caterers following her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ambrose, the head caterer, is making a last minute check of the bar's stock, Quince ambles up, in the background the activity has built to a pitch, waiters adjusting their uni- forms, purveyors' trucks pulling out in a cloud of dust.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Give me a Seagrams and '7'. Ambrose looks at him blankly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No got?  Okay a double V.O., water back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm afraid this is a wine bar, Mr. Quince.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, give me a bottle of wine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Red or white?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Both. Joe appears, looking bewildered, jostled by caterers setting up last-minute tables, a drummer from the band rolls his traps past on a little cart.  Joe doesn't seem to know where he is, when his eyes alight on Quince, he heads for this oasis.  Ambrose sets down two bottles of wine and departs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Red or white?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, thank you. Quince sips the red, now the white, now he pours some of each into one glass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: C'mon, have a drink.  You look like you need one bad as me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do I?  I'm a little confused.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Confused, huh?  About what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Love.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Love'?  Oh, man, I've got troubles of my own.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You love Allison, don't you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh yes, I do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How did you meet?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was a world-class loser and she was a happy, little rich girl -- and for some reason she took me in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But she loves you? Quince smiles, nods embarrassedly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How do you know?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because there's nothing we don't know about each other and it's okay. I mean the deeper, darkest secrets
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: they don't matter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'The deepest, darkest secrets --'?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, it's like you know every inch of each other's souls -- and then you're free.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean 'free'?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Free to love each other.  Com- pletely.  Totally.  No fear. Quince seems uncharacteristically within himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All that hoopla up there reminds me how I will never measure up to a man like Bill Parrish - or his daughter. He drains his wine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you like me, Joe?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh yes, you are one of my favorites.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What would you say if you knew it was me who brought down Bill Parrish? (a moment) I told Drew and the Board that Bill depended on you.  Drew led me on, but I had no business telling him in the first place.  He was setting up Bill from day one.  Drew and Bontecou are going to chop up the company and sell it off for parts. Bontecou was outside, Drew was Mr. Inside.  And I was the fool who made it all happen.  Oh God, what do I do? Joe regards Quince.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go to Bill Parrish and tell him everything.  He'll forgive you. Quince drains one more glass of wine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You think so?  How do you know?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because that's the kind of man Bill Parrish is. A moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, maybe... I guess you know him better than anybody. Another moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Getting to. The orchestra behind them plays a few riffs, sound checks, getting close.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you think I should wait to tell him 'till after the party?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Quince nods anxiously, then smiles gratefully.  They look on as the pre-party activities swirl on around them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The moment just before sunset, the last pre-party minutes, a procession of guests' cars winding up to the guest house, being directed into adjacent fields.  Susan cuts past a re- ceiving line that files up the stairs, she skirts the house and heads straight for the action, the party on the lawns in the rear, climbs a terrace where she commands a view of the event on which the curtain is just about to rise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Guests milling, emerging from the crowd Susan sees, isolated by a fountain, Joe.  He looks up towards her, he knows she has seen him, they proceed to a rendezvous that has not been prearranged but which they intuit.  Susan slants through the guests, stopping here and there, excited greetings and cha- tter float on the wind, "He, Susie!",  "What a party",  "You look great", she keeps moving, a shimmering wraith. Joe is on the right coordinate to meet her, his graceful, unfailing step carrying him speedily to a destination he is not certain of, but where he knows he will find Susan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The very last rays of the sun setting over the wide expanse of river, the light catching Susan and Joe as they enter the garden, the party forming behind them, the river flowing in front of them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I like you in a black tie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love you in an evening gown.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It beats a surgical, doesn't it? He smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Daddy told me you might be leaving?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.  Your father and I, our time together has come to an end.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where are you going? Joe attempts to answer, but nothing comes out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You won't tell me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well -- I -- SUSAN And you can't tell me who you are. Again the same indescribable gesture from Joe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm in love with a man, I don't know who he is, where he's going or when.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can tell you the when part.  Tonight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It gets worse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No worse than it gets for me.  I'm in love with a woman whom I don't want to leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then don't. A moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We know so little about each other -- SUSAN We know all that we need to know -- JOE But there's so much to tell you -- SUSAN Don't.  That will come later.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lightning struck.  We caught it in a bottle.  Don't let it out.  I want to be with you, Joe -- Another moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What will we do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Love will find out the way'.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Love will find out the way'?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a saying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I believe that, don't you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, that's why I said it. They are on the brink of some decision, Joe is about to make some declaration when Allison is heard -- ALLISON (O.S.) There you are! Allison appears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's going on here?  Tete-a-tetes on my big night? (to Susan) C'mon honey, you're needed. (to Joe) Can it wait? But before he can answer -- ALLISON (cont'd) Glad to hear it! (to Susan) Let's go. She takes Susan's arm and marches her off, Joe, in thrall, watches them go as the MUSIC erupts behind them, as 'up' dance tune, a lilting, catchy melody envelops them all.  The curtain has risen on William Parrish's 65th birthday party.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Quince is "on the carpet", sweating through a confession, Parrish moroses but  philosophical at his desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...what can I say after I say that I'm sorry?  I zipped when I should've zagged, I opened my big mouth one too many times, everything got all twisted -- PARRISH It's okay, Quince.  I understand. You've always meant well and I appreciate that.  Sometimes things just turn out -- wrong.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on the door, it opens, Joe appears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me -- He starts to step out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come in, Joe -- I want to thank you
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: okay, Bill?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure. As Joe enters, Quince flashes a warm smile at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe knew the whole story.  I told him.  It was his idea that I come clean.  I mean I wanted to come clean but he gave me a pair of balls, you know what I mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I believe I do. Quince now drifts off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, well -- I can tell you guys got business -- PARRISH No, I'm out of business, right, Quince?  However I do have some unfinished business -- with Drew. Get him out here.  Get him on the chopper and get him out here to- night.  I want to tell this guy how I feel about him face-to-face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, that could be a tall order, B.P. I doubt that Drew's anxious to see you face-to-face. Joe steps in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell Drew that Bill acknowledges that this was a contest and he's lost.  The race is to the swift, but could Drew summon a modicum of understanding and allow Bill to save face.  Tell him Bill wants it understood in the business community he has merely moved upstairs in his own company, and the executive continuity is unbroken.  Tonight's the night to do it.  He'll introduce Drew to his press friends as well as some of his close acquaintances from Washington and Drew can tell them that everything's sailing along just fine. Parrish is impressed by Joe's acumen, a look of grudging admiration.  He nods to Joe, summarizes:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All in all, what Bill wants to do is build the golden bridge to Drew with no hard feelings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You think Drew will go for it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Quince, I've got confidence in you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir, I'll deliver the package. He heads out, Parrish and Joe fall silent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not at all. A moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How are you doing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the hell do you care?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was just asking, Bill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You 'want to know', I'll tell you. You're looking at a man who tonight is not about to walk through the Valley of the Shadow of Death, he's galloping into it.  And the same time, the business he built with his own hands and his own head is being commandeered by a couple of cheap pirates.  And, oh yes, I almost forgot, my daughter's fallen in love with Death. Another moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I'm in love with your daughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Say again?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm in love with your daughter, and I'm taking her with me tonight. Parrish is stunned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think you heard me, Bill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not taking Susan anywhere. And what the hell does that mean anyway? Joe doesn't answer for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought we had a deal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry, Bill -- PARRISH Susan is my daughter, she has a wonderful life ahead of her and you're going to deprive her of it and you're telling me you're sorry?  Well, I'm sorry, apology not accepted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love her, Bill.  She is all that I ever wanted, and I've never wanted for anything because I've never wanted anything before, if you can understand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How perfect for you -- to take whatever you want because it pleases you.  It's not love -- JOE Then what is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some aimless infatuation in which, for the moment, you feel like in- dulging.  It's missing everything that matters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Which is what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Trust, responsibility, taking the weight, for your choices and feel- ings and spending the rest of your life living up to them.  And above all, not hurting the object of your love.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So that's what love is?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Multiply it by infinity and take it to the death of forever and you will still have barely a glimpse of what I am talking about.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Those were my words, Bill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, they're mine now. Joe is silent for a moment, cogitating.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Susan wants to come.  She says she's in love with me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With you?!  Who is 'you'?  Did you tell her who you are?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Does she know where she's going? Joe doesn't answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Susan went, in whatever way she did, for that poor sonofabitch whose body you took, and everything else since has been aftermath.  You say you love her but you don't know what love is. She 'loves' you but she doesn't know who you are.  You make a deal, you're breaking it -- the bottom line is, Joe, you're conducting a Great Romance under false pretenses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't like what you're saying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't expect you to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you threatening me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I certainly hope so -- I loved Susan from the moment she was born, and I love her now, and every minute in between, and what I dream of is a man who will discover her and she will discover a man who will love her, who is worthy of her, who is of this world, of this time and has the grace and compassion and fortitude to walk beside her as she makes her way through this beautiful thing called life. Parrish is beginning to reach Joe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you telling me I can't be part of it? A pause, Parrish's posture changes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why did you come in here and tell me, Joe?  You are the Biggest Shot of all, you don't have to ask my permission, but that's what you're doing.  You know why?  Because you've somewhere, somehow, developed into a good guy, and you know this is all wrong... I don't know what you're going to do -- how can this be love? She doesn't know who you are.  Why don't you tell her?  Try it out on her?  See what happens.  Reveal everything there is to know about yourself and let the chips fall where they may. Joe has received what Parrish has said.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay? -- I've given it my best shot. I wish I could tell you to sleep on it but... Parrish lets his words drift into silence, he shrugs, Joe regards him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe makes his way down the path from Parrish's study, a weight on his shoulders, his step measured, within himself until he is hit by the lights and laughter and MUSIC of the party.  He drifts into the center and runs right into Susan, couples swirl about them, the eye of a storm of gaiety.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, Joe.  What'd you know? She smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's something so indescribably sexy about you in a crowd.  I could make love to you right here. He hesitates, reaches out to take her hand, studies it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you're going to tell my future, you're on the wrong side. A moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is something I do want to tell you -- He stammers into silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you can't. Joe is about to respond but doesn't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just then -- when you hesitated -- the way you shift from foot-to-foot, I've always found endearing but just now -- I got a chill. But he drifts again, now she takes his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Remember that morning in the coffee shop?  You said 'What's wrong with taking care of a woman, she takes care of you --" JOE Did I say that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I said you'd have a hard time finding a woman like that. Joe shifts, she smiles at his embarrasement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, you've found one, Joe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The 'coffee shop' -- SUSAN -- That was the place... and you were the guy. Joe seems resigned now, the air gone out of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you said you didn't want me to be your doctor because you didn't want me to examine you --? (a moment) Well, I got to examine you after all -- Joe blinks, at a loss.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I could come with you -- JOE I - uh -- SUSAN You want me to wait for you, you'll be back -- Joe doesn't answer, Susan is suddenly anxious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why do I want this night to last forever?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't you know, that's what I want more than anything. He touches her face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You said before you couldn't tell me who or where, only the 'when' -- Is when now? A moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: May I kiss you? She waits.  He kisses her, they fall into a deep embrace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That felt like a goodbye. Joe's silence is heavy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's going on, Joe?  I feel like we're lifting off -- JOE I'm still here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you're not.  You're somewhere else. (a moment) You're someone else -- Joe is struggling with a response, finally, inevitably, he drifts into a long silence.  Susan is beside herself, her emotions tossed in every direction, Joe steadies her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me you love me -- tell me you love me now -- JOE I love you now, I'll love you always -- SUSAN Hold me -- He holds on tight to her.  They are desperately entwined until finally she releases him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Susan -- SUSAN -- Yes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you for loving me. She smiles wanly, Joe leaves her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Parrish is seated by the window, lights from the party flashing past, the MUSIC and laughter audible but muted, the fever of the celebration lost on him, within himself. Joe enters, Parrish looks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...We should think about getting started, Bill. Parrish waits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It'll just be us. The tension in Parrish's body releases, he takes a breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. Joe nods an acknowledgement, but his face reflects his pain. Parrish regards him sympathetically. The silence is broken by a KNOCK on the door.  Parrish, out of politeness to Joe, does not respond.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bill --? After a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come in. Quince appears, flushed with excitement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I got him.  The chopper's two minutes away. Parrish weighs the information for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How are we on time? Joe shrugs, nods gently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get him in here. Quince exits, Parrish presses the button for the speaker- phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...May? -- I know you're busy,  but I want you to put in a call to Eddie Sloane for me -- MAY (O.S.) At home, sir --?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, he's at the office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An area on the fringe of the party, the helicopter blades stop spinning.  Quince hurries to the aircraft door, opens it and Drew steps out.  Quince leads the way through the lights and MUSIC.  Drew, fashioning an imperial entrance for himself, hails partygoers as he passes, Quince enjoying the irony.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is damn big of Bill, I also think it's smart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He had no choice.  You're a formidable adversary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He said that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, you've got him by the short- hairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, the short, gray hairs. He flashes a pleased-as-punch greeting to some unseen acquaintance as they press on to Parrish's study.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Parrish is at his desk, Joe in a distant corner of the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're all here, Bill -- PARRISH I appreciate this, Eddie, members of the Board, this will just take a minute of your time.  As the custo- dians of the company, you may re- ceive information from what follows that is valuable to you -- (a moment)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: or not.  Either way, thanks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're all ears. Drew enters with Quince, Quince nods, excusing himself, and closes the door behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, Bill, happy birthday -- A moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just wanted to say how appre- ciative I am of this - uh - grand gesture and -- PARRISH Shut up and sit down. Drew takes a seat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a worthless sack of shit, you fucked me over, played footsie with John Bontecou, sold my company out to line your own pockets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know where you get that idea
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the Board agreed -- PARRISH The Board didn't know you're a mole who burrowed inside so you could bury us all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is this Mr. Black's fantasy?  Another one of his whoppers?  Aren't you sick of this asshole lurking around? No one knows who he is, but one thing everyone does know, he somehow got your ear and has been pouring poison into it ever since. Joe can no longer control himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're the poison, Drew.  You've operated behind-the-scenes to suborn the trust of a man who has stamped you with his imprimatur of class and elegance and stature.  I've seen all kinds and degrees of deception in my time, but Bill Parrish has been on the receiving end of machinations so Machiavellian that it has rarely been my experience to encounter.  And yet he has combatted them stoically, and selflessly, without revealing my identity.  Had he violated the vow of secrecy he took, his task would have been far easier, he could have turned defeat into victory, but he is too honorable a man to have done that.  And now I must release him from that vow.  Because of me, he has lost his work, his company, his reputation -- and now he's going to tell you who I am. Parrish is struck dumb.  He looks at Joe pleadingly, shaking his head imperceptibly, but Joe nods to him blithely -- and then commandingly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So tell me, tell me, I'm peeing in my pants.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And now you're going to pee some more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe, don't do this -- JOE It's time to put this person where he belongs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not necessary, Joe.  Drew's going to step aside -- DREW I'm not stepping anywhere -- JOE I appreciate your gentlemanliness, Bill, but what we need to do here is drive the dagger home -- DREW The dagger --?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I told you to shut up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Prepare yourself, Drew - I am -- PARRISH He is -- JOE I'll take it from here -- (to Drew) I am -- PARRISH -- An IRS man. Drew is stunned, Joe glances at Parrish, hesitates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, he is.  He's an -- IRS man. Aren't you, Joe? Joe is at a loss, Parrish's eyes are glued to his, Joe gets the hint.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I am. (to Drew)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: man. Drew's head swivels from Joe to Parrish and back again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Treasury Department asked my cooperation in his undercover investigation of John Bontecou. They were convinced that Bontecou, on past deals, had structured his mergers and acquisitions in sus- picious and complicated ways so as to evade paying the taxes he is liable for.  The IRS wanted to go after him, and this deal offered them the opportunity. (a moment) I agreed to cooperate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And we're very grateful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Moreover, Agent Joe Black here -- of course that's not his real name
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: smelled out your involvement, Drew.  He developed evidence you were working both sides of the fence.  Unfortunately, that's known as a conflict of interest -- JOE Undisclosed conflict of interest -- PARRISH An offense -- JOE An indictable offense. Silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think I'd like to talk to my lawyer -- PARRISH No lawyers, Drew.  We're going to offer you a deal. Drew is all attention.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Confess to the Board every details of your participation and then submit your resignation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And what do I get?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You get not to go to jail.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're talking through your hat. You're offering a deal because you've got no proof.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Proof?  We've got plenty of proof.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And he's talking through his lips. Joe steps forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Make no mistake, Drew, if you choose to test my resolve in this matter, you'll be looking at an outcome that will have a finality that is beyond your comprehension, and you'll not be counting the days or the months or the years, but millenniums in the house with no doors. Drew slumps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, you win.  As soon as I get back to the city, I'll meet with the Board. Sloane's voice erupts over the SPEAKERPHONE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're meeting with the Board right now, Drew.  Resignation accepted. Moreover, I propose a motion to re- confirm William Parrish as Chairman of the Board of Parrish Communica- tions as well as a rejection of the merger with Bontecou International. How say you, Board? A chorus of thunderous "Yes"es resounds through the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The motion is passed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, thank you, that's great, but it's more than I bargained for.  I just wanted to set the record straight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But we want you back, Bill.  Mean- while, enjoy your party, celebrate, we'll attend to the nasty details. And Mr. Black, may we say thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My pleasure.  This is an IRS Agent's dream.  I'll be promoted to Chief of Section off of this. Parrish clicks the speakerphone off.  Drew is staring at Joe, shaking his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who would've ever believed it?  You, an IRS Agent -- Silence.  Joe shrugs, smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Death and Taxes'. The door flies open, an anxious Allison appears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Daddy!  We've been looking all over for you - this is your party - what are you doing in here?  Never mind. You're on.  Let's go. She pulls him out of his chair, hustles him out of the room, Joe right behind them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The guests have formed themselves into a huge audience, the orchestra strikes up "Happy Birthday" as Parrish appears with Allison.  An enormous cake is unveiled with one great, lit candle, Parrish beams then laughs.  He pauses over the cake, now blows the candle out.  APPLAUSE, cries of "Speech! Speech!", Parrish tries to demur but the request becomes loud and rhythmic, he holds up his hand, nods, quiets the crowd.  Joe observes from the fringe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought I was going to sneak away tonight...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: of "No!"  "Never!"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...What a glorious night, every face I see is a memory.  It may not be a perfectly perfect memory -- sometimes we had our ups and downs
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: but we're all together, and you're mine for a night. (a moment)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I'm going to break precedent, and tell you my one-candle wish -- that you would have a life as lucky as mine, where you can wake up one morning and say "I don't want anything more." (another moment) Sixty-five years - don't they go by in a blink? Parrish hesitates, waves and steps away, APPLAUSE that grows into CHEERS, the music resumes, another dance tune.  Quince grabs him, pumps his hand and claps him on the back.  Now Parrish spots Allison, he wraps her in a tight embrace, they hold each other close for a moment, but then are separated by a surge of guests.  Parrish sees Susan, she smiles but there is a tinge of sadness about her.  He heads towards her, they are somehow situated as if they were alone in this crowd.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What a night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm having a helluva time. A moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You were right about Joe, he is going somewhere -- PARRISH (gently) I'm sorry. Susan is examining Parrish very closely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you relieved?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, but -- Parrish hesitates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want you to know how much I love you.  That you've given a meaning to my life that I had no right to expect, and that no one can ever take from me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Daddy -- PARRISH No -- I love you so much and I want you to promise me something.  I don't want you to ever worry about me.  If anything should happen, I'm going to be fine and everything's going to be all right. (a moment)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I have no regrets. Susan is in pain now, she can't summon an answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I want you to feel that way, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love you, Daddy -- PARRISH That's why it's okay. They drift into silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No regrets? After a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'No regrets'. A long silence, Susan smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a good feeling, isn't it? Silence again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everybody's saying goodbye... They regard each other, a long pause, they have reached an understanding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm still here. (a moment) Would you like to dance with me, Susan?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, yes -- He starts to lead her to the floor, immediately stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you don't mind dancing with an old fogey like me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Dad, you're not old.  You'll never be old. He takes her in his arms and they dance away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On a distant fringe of the party, a grass terrace that still commands a view of the dance floor, is Joe.  His eyes are on Parrish and Susan, he watches them admiringly yet ruefully. A Waiter passes, catches sight of Joe, stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can I get you anything, sir? Joe regards the Waiter for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you have any peanut butter? The Waiter hesitates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think so, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, anyway. The Waiter moves off.  Joe's attention returns to Parrish and Susan, the dance number ends, a BOOM.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On the dance floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What was that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The fireworks are about to start. Parrish looks up, sees Joe up on the terrace, waiting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shall we?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You go ahead, honey, I'm going to catch my breath. Suddenly he hugs her, holds her very close.  She looks at him, he smiles, nods, but doesn't release her until she smiles back.  Now she heads out with the crowd for the fireworks.  When Parrish senses she is on her way, he turns and heads up towards Joe. Joe rises to meet Parrish as he approaches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Happy Birthday, Bill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. They watch the guests gathering to view the fireworks. Joe's gaze lingers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you say goodbye?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not exactly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess you have your reasons.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now that we have a moment, would you mind if I expressed my gratitude for what you did for Susan? Joe waits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I never heard her speak of any man as she spoke of you -- It was always what I wanted for her -- but what happens to her now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wouldn't worry about it, Bill. These things have a way of working out. Joe regards Parrish, waits until he has a sense that Parrish has accepted what Joe has said, then Joe continues:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And would you mind if I expressed my gratitude...? Parrish waits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For you.  For the time you've given me.  For the person you are. A moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't blow smoke up my ass, you'll ruin my autopsy. Joe barely manages a smile, now looks back longingly at the crowd below, searching.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's hard to let go, isn't it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's life.  What can I tell you? A silence, an understanding there is another more to say. Joe looks inquiringly at Parrish as if to say "Shall we?", Parrish nods and Joe turns with him.  They set off now away from the party, up a meadow that leads to a hill overlooking the river.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Down below, the party guests' faces are lit by the initial fireworks display.  Among them is Susan, but her interest isn't there.  Not something pulls her attention, an over- powering feeling that compels her to turn and see, at a distance, Parrish and Joe walking away up the meadow.  Some- thing about the sight saddens and at the same time frightens her, she turns back to the party, dazed, tracing on the fireworks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Up the hill Parrish's step slows, Joe slowing with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm getting a little dizzy, I can feel my heart pumping -- But Parrish doesn't wait for a response, just continues on up the meadow, towards the rise of the hill, Joe in step with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Should I be afraid? Joe stops, Parrish stops with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not a man like you. Parrish smiles faintly, takes a deep breath, he strides out again, Joe right with him.  In tandem they continue on and disappear over the crest of the hill.  A barrage of fireworks lights up the sky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Down below, Susan, in a pained reflex, again turns and looks up towards the hill.  There is nobody there.  She hesitates, now glides away from the party, her step quickens as she walks up towards the hill. Susan halts, in the distance a figure is approaching from over the crest of the hill where Joe and Parrish disappeared. He is heading straight for her, she tries to make him out, seems to recognize him, starts to walk towards him as if pulled by a magnet.  Now she stops again.  It is a man, he keeps coming, and now that he is close and recognizes him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe...? He smiles quizzically, hasn't quite heard her, stands right in front of her, loose, smiling, disoriented and yet so appealing.  They are riveted on each other, uneasy and yet close.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're here... He is trying to get his bearings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You bet. Something about him makes Susan slightly tentative.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where did you go? Joe shrugs, scratches his head endearingly, uncertain of time and place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know -- y'know, I don't know
direction.name: direction
